description:
Great iconic restaurant in the Castro. Service is very attentive and friendly. Coffee is fresh and made locally. The food was good. 

I had the omelet with toast and hash browns. The omelet was soft and had just the right amount of filling. Prices were reasonable. Lots of regulars come here.  

They have all you can drink mimosa.
author: Alan H.

description:
I just had breakfast there and My server added the tip like 18% on the check automatically without even consulting with me.... it is illegal to do this! 
I am a server in a restaurant and I will never do this to anyone. This is very disrespectful and disappointing.... 
I don't want to come back to this place ever but the management has to know about this because this server would have gotten 20% foor sure because that is what I always tip, but he just got the shity 18% that he added to himself....
author: Daniela T.

description:
If you never have been to The Cove in the Castro you are missing a lot. We love this place, the wonderful and friendly staff and not to mention the owners Solange and Maurice. They are doing a fabulous job running this place. 

The Cove is one of the true last standing amazing little cafes that has that family vibe. Great mimosas and great atmosphere! The food is delicious, I have so many favorite items on their menu. The eggs Benedict and the French toast are some of my favorites.
author: Miguel B.

description: This is my favorite place in castro. The staff is so friendly and never forget a face.
author: Victoria Y.

description:
We end up at the Cove on Castro every time we wake up in the mood for breakfast.  It is a small little cafe in the heart of Castro. It is what you would expect for a simple diner type of cuisine. It is nothing special or fancy but it is hearty and the service is usually great.

My wife loves their orange juice which is most of the reason she loves the mimosas as well.  As far as the food goes they have your typical breakfast options such as pancakes and eggs but they also have a few healthy items that we come for. 

We usually get the South Beach breakfast or the Ironman Breakfast. Both of these are low carb and protein friendly meals. They have egg white and chicken apple sausage options that are not always available at all eateries. 

All in all you know what you are getting when you come to  a place like this. If you are in the mood for breakfast I would recommend stopping by and enjoying a mimosa.
author: Danielle B.

description: Excellent service! Everyone that worked there who walked by us checked on us, not just our waiter. The atmosphere is calm (at least during the early afternoon while we were there), with people reading newspapers and books, enjoying their lunch. I had the turkey sandwich with the tomato bisque which was excellent, btw. My friend had a cheeseburger with fries. We cleaned our plates!  would definitely return!
author: Charles B.

description:
This is an OK diner-food type place. The staff is mainly ok, it's not the most friendly service but gets the job done. The menu itself is not too extensive. 

I decided on the 2-2-2, which is eggs, bacon or sausage, and pancakes or French toast. The eggs are a bit oily, the bacon was fine for a thicker cut, but the French toast was a little disappointing. It looked fine but was a little undercooked so it was soggy in parts. 

The prices are a little high for what you get.
author: Spencer H.

description: I had the best burger here! Brie burger with onions and sweet potato fries. Server was extra friendly and quick! The restaurant was modern and colorful. Parking was not easy but we got our exercise.
author: Debbie v.

description:
This is a no frills diner in the heart of San Francisco's Castro District. 

The servers are welcoming, and informative not to mention the food arrives rather quickly and hot to boot.  A friend and I dropped in for a "petit dejeuner" (a little breakfast) ordering two soups and sandwiches.

At $12.95 they make an excellent BLT. Perfect toast with crisp lettuce, a thick sliced tomato one can actually taste enough bacon to contrast all these textures and flavors. For the accompanying cup of soup they offer several "soup du jour" (soup of the day) choices we did not find overly salty, thanks guys. 

At $14.95 the Sourdough Special with fresh turkey breast, bacon, tomato and Swiss was equally good yet I found the grilled bread to be just a bit greasy for my tastes. Don't get me wrong, for a grilled sandwich this was above average, not overly greasy, thanks again.
author: Caesar A.

description: The hot chocolate is amazing! Coffee and key lime pie also fantastic. Great service and really comfortable environment.
author: Katie S.

description: We ordered the 2 + 2 + 2. Had 2 eggs sunny side up, pancakes and sausage. Coffee was delicious! And the cranberry juice came in and Tall frosted glass mug. Perfection! Not overpriced and delicious food. Happy smiling workers too!
author: Tracie A.

description: Meh. Our brunch was ok. My pancakes tasted like spice cakes as they were heavy on the cinnamon and other spices. I wouldn't order them again. Hubby's benedict was a highlight. A couple things were disappointing, like watching a server put a full plastic canister of ice directly on the floor, being asked to move from a 4 top to a 2 top after being seated and receiving drinks (watching the table sit empty for our entire meal), and waiting forever for our check to be picked up and then returned even though the place was half full. I'd rather wait in line at Orphan Andy's any day. Adios Cove.
author: James S.

description: I got a basic 2 eggs and bacon to go and it was cooked to perfection and the service was super sweet.  Highly recommended breakfast spot in the Castro.
author: Meagan M.

description:
Food:

Biscuits and Gravy - This was an OK dish.  I can't say that when I looked at it visually that it was stunning but it was good in taste.  I can't really say that I'm a connoisseur in Biscuits and Gravy either but for some odd reason I was craving it.

Service: Friendly and attentive waitstaff.

Ambiance: Just your everyday neighborhood spot.  Seems like a lot of people that live in the area will come here for a bite.

Overall: I'd be willing to give other dishes a try go forward but not going to be a go to place on my list.
author: Spencer Q.

description: It been over 20 years since I ate here the food is ok but it has been that way forever. Due to the changes in the Castro area it has lost it atmosphere, charm and the feel is not really welcoming. Sorry to say would not recommend
author: Dennis C.

description:
I ordered eggs scrambled soft and got the most overcooked eggs I have ever experienced - could not eat them. Bacon was soft and lacked any crunch.

Their whole gig is cooking breakfast. How could they get these two staples of American breakfast so wrong? I will definitely not go back and will steer others clear of this place.
author: Jack M.

description: I've  been going to the Cove for many years. The food is fabulous. The servers are fabulous. And they have the best fried chicken in the Castro.  Great soups and a great atmosphere ! My favorite place in the Castro to eat and I recommend it to every out-of-towner I meet !
author: Scottie I.

description:
First and last time I'm coming here. I bought breakfast for my partner and I and we both ordered chicken fried steaks with gravy, eggs, hash browns and a side of fruit.
The egg yolks were over cooked and the white part of my eggs were undercooked (HOW does that even happen???)
The chicken fried steak was rubbery and bland AND slightly cold.
The hash browns looked and tasted like they had been sitting out or even reheated and were SATURATED in grease.
My toast was kind of charred.
(The worst part was the fruit.)
The fruit looked old and I bit into a piece of watermelon that tasted of mold, they bring us another and again there's black mold on the berries and the pineapple looks brown. They bring a third 'apology' plate of fruit only minutes later with our waiter saying that "the cook just cut fresh fruit for this one" which was false because half the fruit looked old. (I too work in a restaurant and work with fresh produce so I can tell the difference)
That was the last straw.
My partner and I left feeling sick and disappointed and he got diarrhea.
If you want to spend $40 on a mediocre breakfast you can easily make yourself for a fraction of the price then come on down to the cove. That's the cost of being lazy.
author: NoeBear G.

description: This place is fine. It's not good or bad or anything really. It's basically food you'd cook at home if you weren't really into cooking. Except of course you don't have to cook. Standard diner fare, standard preparation. The people are nice but not great at their jobs, the place is slightly pleasant in a kinda dive-y way and there are naked men being displayed on monitors.
author: Daniel E.

description: Always consistently great. I love love love the Mexican turkey burger! The best turkey burger in the city
author: Skot L.

description:
This place is a local diner feel with all the staple breakfast taste and menu.  The service is friendly and helpful.  Has a pleasant local feel and the servers knew a few of the people who walked in the door.  This is your no frills diner and there are no specialty or uniquely tasty items.  The location is across from the Castro Theater and I loved people watching by the window.

Overall, I liked the experience more than the food, however all orders were made fresh and served fast.
author: Mee-Jin Y.

description:
Came here for bottomless brunch on a Monday! You only pay $14 for the bottomless brunch but you do have to purchase a meal. Food in San Francisco is generally overpriced so this breakfast place was too.
They make good mimosas! They were nice and strong.
They also have fresh squeezed orange juice which is an added bonus. At one point she ran out of the oj so gave us pomegranate juice which I thought was even tastier!
The cove on Castro has a fun vibe to it. Service is good and food was tasty as well.  I recommend their pancakes and French toast.
Definitely come here for the mimosas! Well worth it.
author: Kamila M.

description: This place is a nice Castro restaurant to go after a couple of happy hour drinks or before a serious night out.  The food is so-so, the servers are great and the mood is always festive.
author: Andrew S.

description: Ambiance great.  Service good.  Food - cheap, greasy diner food - at a San Francisco price.  If you are looking for delicious, handcrafted, or healthy food, avoid this place.  If you're looking for greasy diner food, then you will be in heaven!
author: Lynn E.

description:
I was disappointed. I tried the special; it was not special as what was delivered was not the description in the menu. The entree had an odd pineapple, bad Cantonese-American consistency.
The waiter could not have been nicer. I will not return. I confused the Cove with Mystique. I could not figure out what was so different. I am glad I tried it; I will not go back.
author: Lawrence L.

description:
I originally gave the cove 5 stars but after today's lunch, I could only give 1 star in good conscience.

I ordered the BBQ roast beef platter, which was just thinly sliced cooked beef that was then thrown on the grill. It was dry but in all fairness I ordered it without the sugar-packed BBQ sauce. The issue was the pathetic rip-off portion, the tiny cup of soup as my side and the awful coleslaw, that the waitress said had a sour taste because of the apple cider vinegar in it. Yuck.
author: Bulldog W.

description: The waiter was wonderful and gracious! The chorizo scramble was more chorizo and vegetables than I expected and toast was heavily buttered, which I love. Coffee was fresh and wasn't so strong that I couldn't finish two cup. So good, and was sorely needed
author: Nicole T.

description: I had a craving for soup & sandwich. I ordered a black forest ham & cheddar sandwich with white bean soup & it was perfect. Why 4 instead of 5 stars?  They should offer a soup & half-sandwich plate which we thought we ordered. Still a great classic lunch spot in the Castro & we love that they are here.
author: Scott F.

description: After seeing an additional charge of $2.50 if you wanted maple syrup with your pancakes (!) I opted for the French Dip. The food arrived fast enough. It was bland though, and it had an off taste. The portion size was also small for the price. Not that I would have finished it I guess had it been a bigger sandwich.
author: Kale F.

description:
I use to rate this place much higher...but I no longer go there!  I use to go there often with 6 friends - we would spend over $100/visit.  

We went there on Saturday March 4th.  One of our group members was downtown so he was on his way.  The 5 of us were told we had to wait until the 6th person arrived!!!!!!  I told the woman (her name is Olivia, I believe) the 6th person will not be there for a bit so we would have coffee and wait for him.  She refused to seat the 5 of us. Really?  She said she would not seat us until all are present...she was rude and VERY CONDENSENDING!. A younger waiter stood behind her saying the same thing...he was just sheepish. There were many seats open. I told many of my friends and some of them have also experienced Olivia and her rudeness.   The Cove is a neighbor dinner..........not an upscale restaurant!  

NEVER AGAIN!  Olivia makes The Cover VERY unappealing.  We will not longer go there.  We have found other neighborhood restaurant, in Hayes Valley, such as Stacks or Harvey's down Castro Street as well as Orphan Andy just a few steps away round the corner off Castro Street.  I find it sad that someone with a rude, arrogant and "uppity," attitude can really work with the pupil.
author: John M.

description: Always look forward to visiting The Cove while vacationing in my favorite city. Every experience is a fabulous one!! Great Food and Super Friendly Staff..
author: Marc K.

description: Probably one of the best burgers I've ever had.  Obviously hand pressed and very fresh.   Fries were great and beer was served in a chilled glass mug.  I enjoyed the atmosphere, the music on the radio, and the service.
author: Matry P.

description: I disdain paying for a mediocre meal. I ordered the dinner special, beef brisket served with a side of coleslaw and fries . The brisket lacked flavor and the fries were extremely stale, evidently re-fried. As for the service, I have no complaints. The staff is attentive and cordial. I am just disappointed that I had to pay for subpar food, considering someone else had recommended this place with such enthusiasm. I cannot see why.
author: Daisy M.

description: Twice cooked hamburger. I ordered medium rare and got a medium well done. No taste. Overpriced and over cooked. They tried to tell me the center of the patty was cooked medium rare. Are you freakin kidding me? We have been going to this place for several years, but never again.
author: Kevin L.

description: THE STAFF...sweet. Everyone so welcoming & they customized my food Anni was a sweetheart so was Mohmad I cant wait to come back ugh BOTTOMLESS MIMOSAS yass queen
author: Rosa R.

description: This was my first visit, but won't be my last. The staff was very attentive and friendly without being intrusive. The food was WONDERFUL!!! We had the white bean soup, salmon salad, meatloaf and hamburger with the NEST fries!!! The price was very reasonable for the quality and quantity. Definitely a great place to eat!!!
author: Phyllis N.

description:
One of our favorite family owned restaurant in the Castro.  Food is great, service is great and the owners are always there working and so kind. 
Great great place!
author: Stacey P.

description:
This may not be one of those memorable meal kind of places but the food is solid and the service warm.   In fact the place is designed to be comfortable.

I lucked into having one of two window tables.  With great views since two sides of the table are glass and the Castro Theater across the street.

Even if you don't get a window there are monitors all over showing pictures old and new of the neighborhood  and its people.

For lunch I had the Cove Burger a Brie cheeseburger that comes with fries.  It was really good.  I'm sure I'll be back.
author: Mark B.

description: Yummy chicken noodle soup. And the greyhound, a tasty drink!
author: Fernandine F.

description:
Came here for brunch with my roomies. The space is located in the castro and has tons of seating inside. 

Service: The staff was super friendly and our waiter constantly checked up on us to make sure we were enjoying our time there. 

Food: It was meh for me. Nothing too different from other brunch places in the area/SF. 

They have a great location with great staff, and I wish I could give them more stars, but the food just didn't meet my expectations of the place.
author: Keizzel C.

description:
An oasis of calm, tasty food served by attentive staff. Busy on the weekends and a bit more relaxed during the week, a solid performer. 
Enjoy!
author: William M.

description: Great food but kinda stingy on the bottomless mimosas. Takes a while for refills. Lol.
author: Tyler B.

description:
I stopped by Cove on a rainy Saturday afternoon. It's was 2 pm already, but my friend and I were craving for pancakes. And Cove serve their Breakfast till 4 pm!!! We ended up getting buttermilk pancakes and buckwheat pancakes, adding extra maple syrup and blueberries. The food came out fast and with a very generous amount of blueberries. 
Our server was very attentive and sweet, we got our water glasses refilled several times during the meal. The ambiance is cozy, the staff is friendly and warm-hearted. I guess a lot of clients are regulars, who enjoy their food while having a nice conversation with a friend, or reading a newspaper. 
There are 2 tv screens on the walls, and the one by the door kept on showing all my favorite music videos, though mute. Pleasure for the eyes!:)
author: Katie K.

description: The Cove has great service and superb burgers. they grind the meat themselves! Really homie ambiance, very chill vibes. would def. recommend.
author: Annelissa R.

description:
My friend and I ate here for brunch and bottomless mimosas before going to a singalong at the Castro Theater right across the street. 

I ordered the Carnivore Scramble, and it was pretty good. Is there really much to complain about with eggs, cheese, Irish bangers, bacon, and ham? The bangers were pretty tasty. They had a peppery and earthy flavor from maybe coriander, sage, and nutmeg. 

We also had an order of the buckwheat pancakes, and we both liked them. They were fluffy and had a warm nutmeg or mace flavor to them. The syrup was just sweet and didn't taste that maple-y, but it was fine considering CoC is just a low key neighborhood diner. 

There were two mimosas available that day: a regular and strawberry lime one. The regular mimosa wasn't anything remarkable. It just kinda tasted like watered down orange juice. I thought the strawberry lime one was better. It was sweeter and tasted more fruity. Can't really go wrong with bottomless booze for $10.95, and it was perfect for lubricating our vocal cords.
author: Nei N.

description:
I went to this hidden gem for the first time on 11/11/16. I loved everything about it and wondered why I hadn't tried it out before. 

Recommendations:
1. Tomato Bisque Soup (comes with two wheat bread toasts)
2. Chicken Marsala (does not come with pasta)
3. Vegetarian Cove Curry (you can pick between brown rice or basmati rice)

I loved the food and the service. The staff is very friendly and they come by often to check if you need anything. 

I love their menu. It's big and lots of variety. I love that they have so many choices for the soup too. 

The food tasted really fresh and they were able to adjust the spice level for me upon request. 

I would go there again in a heartbeat. 

Great for vegetarians! 

Great spot for Breakfast/Brunch/Lunch/Dinner :)

Easy to get a table. 

Easy for a big group meal too as well as kid-friendly.
author: Hiral P.

description:
Today I walked in the Cove ( I've been a customer for years) and was greeted by the manager with..." The bathroom is only for paying customers..." WHAT??..
I guess I didn't pass the Cove dress and social standards. Maybe I'm too overweight for all the skinny twink boys that populate their sacred premises.. OR ..maybe my hoodie was the wrong color... OR ...maybe my skin is the wrong color (too dark, to darken their manager's door of the burning cross)...fuming and really pissed off I went across the street for a coffee and pastry. I called the Cove, stated my grievances, and they sent out a wait person to "explain" the manager's repulsive actions towards me. I demanded an apology face to face from the manager...waited 20 minutes and never got one. This is one for City Hall, various local newspapers,  and the NAACP...more later!
author: Michael D.

description: I had an early supper there last Sunday afternoon around 4:30 and ordered a vegeburger with a cup of chicken noodle soup.  By 9:00 that evening, I was feeling naseous.  My stomach gurgled all night long keeping me awake.  The next morning I went to the ER and spent nearly 7 hours there.  A sonogram of my stomach showed a swollen stomach, and the attending doctor said I would must likely expel the contents before the end of the day.  Well, he was right. And I could tell that it was the vegeburger!  Makes me wonder how long that vegeburger was sitting around in the freezer.  I'm sure there's not a high turnover of them.  The other noticeable thing, the iceberg lettuce was half wilted.  I tore off the wilted half and put the crispier half on my burger.  I don't know if the lettuce was tainted or not.  I called the Cove today and told them, and they said to call back tomorrow when the manager is there.  I hope they don't serve any vegeburgers in the meantime.
author: Jon P.

description:
I noticed several customers sit down & order without so much as taking a peek at the menu. I long to have  that kind of connection with a Castro eatery because I love the neighborhood, but Cove isn't going to be that restaurant for me. 

My friend's healthy breakfast of chicken and veggies appeared to be microwaved, compromising the dish's textures, flavors, and overall appeal. My corned beef hash was equally poor in quality and appearance. When I didn't box up the considerable portion I left behind, a woman (perhaps the owner?) asked, "You didn't like your meal?" I didn't, but there was no point in telling her so as my friend & I had decided from the first bite that we wouldn't be returning. 

The Cove might be a winner to many, but their drab breakfast didn't win us over.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Standard diner fare. Nothing really stood out about it. I kind of prefer Orphan Andy's, mostly because of the location... excellent people watching.

Cove is fine, but it didn't really do anything for me. Food was okay. Service was okay. Prices were okay. But I can't think of anything special about it to write. It's... fine.
author: Sean B.

description:
I love the Cove. I don't go to the Castro often but I had my haircut at Louie's next door so I popped in for my fave (eggs benedict).

The staff are just charming and I always enjoy myself there. For some reason it's relaxing and the food is comfort food.

Yup  It's cool
author: Trev O.

description:
THE BENEDICTS! 

Soooo good. It was my second time going to the Cove and it won't be my last.  Great food, friendly and quick service, local, and fun!   My Louisiana Benedict was delicious.
author: Aaron M.

description:
I just had the best meal in m life. The Code make an Indian style Chicken Curry, its just amazing and very healthy. People here are very friendly. 
I love this dish and I highly recommend it.
author: Maher S.

description:
My first time here today was pretty good. While it was insanely busy, we were seated pretty quickly and brought our beverages fast. 

I ordered a ham and Gruyere cheese crepe and it was brought to me lightening quick and they cooked my over easy eggs perfectly. The crepe itself was ok too but seemed small for the priciness. However it was served with mixed fruit and was very fresh. 

Our entire order was handled by three different people which was strange but the experience was pleasant.
author: Christopher S.

description:
Walked in off the street. Attention immediate. Service rapid and very efficient. Not bad for 1 PM on a Monday. Clean, hygienic, and the food was excellent in presentation and preparation. And tasted great! Easy to find... Directly across Castro ST from The Castro Theater and about half a block south of a stop for the 24 Bus NB or SB. As one would expect in the Castro, very accepting to those of any sexuality orientation or predilection including customers on either side of me who appeared to be straight tourists from out of town. 
So this place offers acceptance and great food for everyone. I recommend it without reservation.
author: Phil T.

description: I love coming here for breakfast, a true gem in the Castro. The service is always very friendly, and the menu has a wide variety to choose from. My absolute favorite has always been the Irish Bennedict, which comes with a delicous corned-beef hash.
author: Bryan M.

description:
I come here EVERY time I'm in SF. Friendly people, great food and a great atmosphere. Love the slide show on the TV screen! Historical pics of Castro, fun clips. It's gay proud and a place I could bring mom, too.
:-)
author: Rob R.

description: The Cove on Castro is one of my favorite spots in San Francisco. I lived in the City for 17 years, and now I make sure to stop in every time I'm in town. It's a delicious diner and is a true gem. It's where the locals go for brunch and bottomless mimosas. It's where Castro dwellers commune in celebration as well as mourning, and where we recover after late nights of partying. It's the Cheers of of all-American restaurants. And the vegetarian omelette rocks. The service is friendly and fast and playful. I love this place.
author: Boston B.

description: This is a really dumb restaurant who over charges for crappy food. I told them this in their face and now I am 86'd. Bad way to fix the issue of your crappy food. You should probably just make it better.
author: Matthew M.

description:
I had not eaten in 20 years. But I am glad that I did so tonight.

Ribs and Fries, tonight's special, were excellent. Dinner salad was perfect.

Service was great and food came out fast.
author: scott h.

description:
The Cove on Castro is a casual diner located in the heart of The Castro district directly across from the theatre. It offers a rather simple menu specializing in breakfast/brunch.

The establishment itself is quite small; it provides approx. 15 somewhat-compact tables, and even those feel quite cramped in the space allotted. Though, if one can manage to secure a seat, the interior decor and sunlight shining through the window usually make the Cove an ideal place to begin the day.

As previously stated, the menu is simple--but what the Cove does offer, it prepares fairly nicely. Its eggs and pancakes are among the better that I've tried in San Francisco. The prices are fairly reasonable as well--you won't break the bank grabbing a quick brunch.

Now for the bad: I specify a "quick" brunch for a reason. I have never seen any place as anxious to get customers out the door as the Cove. 

Its customer service is abysmal and I will certainly not return--which is a bummer, because I enjoyed everything else.

My friend and I ordered the (not-) bottomless mimosas for $13.95 this past Wednesday morning. We were poured only one glass before being told bluntly that "we only refill for people when they order food." It stated nowhere on the menu that a food purchase was required, but we obliged nonetheless.

Three mimosas later, our waiter seemed to be getting impatient and kept asking if we "want anything else?" We politely replied "no thanks, we'll just drink a few more mimosas."

About 10 minutes later, he brought our check without asking us. I assumed this was merely a convenience measure.

Nope.

Dude just straight-up quit serving us. He refused to look our way. He wouldn't even walk in our general direction. He simply decided that we had consumed our last mimosa--a decision he neglected to share with us.

Refusing to believe what I was witnessing, I eventually caught his attention and waived him over. 

He didn't come.

Instead, he promptly alerted the manager who reluctantly walked over, filled our glasses once more and candidly said, "this is one for the road."

Yes--we were being shooed out after just one hour and five mimosas. Now, I graduated college only three months ago--five mimosas do absolutely nothing for me.

I left sober and dissatisfied.

It was a rather slow morning; over half of the available tables were empty. No one was waiting for a spot. The staff wasn't busy. The Cove just decided we'd had the equivalent of "bottomless" and sent us on our merry way.

I've never seen anything like it, and hopefully never do again.

Also, there seems to be an issue with the homeless randomly wandering in and around the building. A disheveled man wearing nothing but a half-opened robe entered while we ate and began bothering patrons. It took close to a full minute for staff to respond and request that he leave. When one finally did act, it appeared that he knew the man and had dealt with him before. Just another run-of-the-mill Wednesday at The Cove I presume. Certainly not the most comforting scene to eat your breakfast to.

Overall, this place is OK. Largely forgettable, but OK. If you're in a rush or don't plan to order the bottomless mimosas, it may be for you.

As for me, I won't be back.
author: Kyle P.

description:
The service is always friendly and nice, attentive. 

But the food was underwhelming, slightly overpriced and under-portioned.  Half a waffle, two tiny sausages, and two eggs for $12....  Let's think about that.  I should've taken a picture. 

Cafe Mystique, check it out.

And side note, if I'm paying $4 for coffee, it should be Four Barrel.
author: R B.

description: I ordered "fresh squeezed orange juice". I'm pretty sure it wasn't fresh squeezed. They handed it right out to me and there was no pulp in it. False Advertisement.
author: Kristy A.

description:
My first and likely last visit to this iconic place. First, the positive points: nice ambiance, free WiFi, and the host was very friendly and hospitable. 

I had the black bean burger with onion rings. The ORs were good though the serving was rather modest. The black bean burger was disappointing. The "burger" was essentially a heap of mashed black beans with some seasoning. Not bad flavor, but did not hold up. The bun was just like the buns from some fast food chain and the alottment of lettuce, tomatoes, and onions was shamefully paltry.

I had a "glass" of house wine that was more like a shot than an actual serving of wine. 

Now for the main reason for the low rating: service. The waiter had an attitude, corrected me with "please" when I was ordering, never checked on me, and tossed the check. Never asked if I wanted desert nor how my experience was. It's like I was an inconvenience to him, or maybe I wasn't his type. Regardless, I won't be going back and I suggest going to one of the many other wonderful restaurants in the area.
author: Coby L.

description:
Went here for the first time this week. Service was extremely slow. We both had the same thing, The Cove Special, 2 eggs, 2 strips of bacon and HALF of a Belgian Waffle, 2 coffees.
Eggs weren't done right, requested "crisp" bacon wasn't. The PRE-tip bill was $33.00!
Ridiculously expensive for what you get. Never going back.
author: Robert G.

description:
Places like the Cove make me love the Castro even more. 

When most brunch places in the city charge $13-$16 for eggs benedict, here it's a reasonable $12 and the eggs are PERFECTLY poached and drizzled with a knockout homemade hollandaise sauce! 

I spied a goat cheese omelette made with artichokes, tomatoes and pesto. Oh. My. Can you say flavor explosion?!  

Sure, there's nothing fancy about hashbrowns and toast with your preferred egg dishes, but it's the great American fare, homey atmosphere and regulars lovingly interacting with the staff that make me want to come back... Like, soon!
author: Janice C.

description: This was my second time at the Cove. I ordered felafel again which were OK the first time around and the only vegan option on the menu aside from the bean soup. This time however the felafel were burnt. When I pointed it out to the server her only comment was "well you see felafel are quite difficult to cook and our cooks cannot get the balance right: other not cooked in the middle or burnt in the outside". I looked at her and bit my tongue  to avoid sarcastic comments on how they might reconsider the cooks employment or removing the felafel on the menu altogether. The ambience is nice and I understand it is an institution on the Castro but they should really have a little think. I would not recommend but no need to avoid: it's a felafel Russian roulette!
author: Davide S.

description: I had the buckwheat pancakes. They were light, fluffy, tasty, huge! Almost couldn't finish them. Good coffee too! Even better people watching
author: Cynthia O.

description: The service here was great. The food was just okay; typical diner food. I did like the onion rings because the batter stayed on the onion, no pulling the onion out of the batter and being left with empty fried dough. Definitely have had better, but have also had worse..
author: Kasey N.

description: Pretty gross. I love a greasy spoon, but my food was bland (rare for corned beef hash) and the hash browns were an inedible hard shell with mush inside. All this with a coffee for $18.  I'm a little shocked at the bill, c'mon SF.
author: Brenda H.

description:
Cozy, homey and nothing fancy.  There are very sweet people that work here and really make you feel comfortable.
I had the Cobb Salad today.  It was huge and left me quite happy.
Iceberg lettuce, diced tomatoes, avocado, hard boiled eggs, bacon, blue cheese, diced chicken served with a side of blue cheese dressing.
author: Thomas D.

description: This place is great if you're just looking for a casual diner to get a standard breakfast. The vibe is very east coast. The food will fill you up and you won't be unhappy, but you'll likely never think "wow, that was a delicious meal!" My thoughts are usually more, "wow, I'm glad I'm no longer hungry and that breakfast was relatively inexpensive!"
author: Mike W.

description: I came here for brunch a couple times and the food was very tasty and the bottomless mimosas are refreshing and delicious. I love the eggs benedict. The employees are very quick to take your order and there is usually seating available at most times.
author: Nicholas F.

description:
Our default spot to grab lunch or dinner if we don't want to cook.

The longstanding staff are wonderful and I never fail to be charmed by Solange. Their club sandwich, patty melt, onion rings, cobb salad, tomato soup, and fish and chips can't be beat.

However, recently we've noticed some problems with both food and service during evening hours when we see less-familiar staff in the dining room (and I assume kitchen). Over the past few months we've had a few minor misfires that we've chalked up to new staff needing training. I assume this is the case and Solange and company will get things back to their usual wonderful experience.
author: Mark K.

description: Solange and her husband have kept with the times, updated to perfection. Menu updated to meet the peoples choice. We had to wonderful meals and could not ask for more, Sunday brunch was over the top fun, place was packed and the chef hands down one of the best ... I love the place and will be back more and more, they r a ICON to the hood and people should remember not many place have stood the test of time... They have and rocked it even more so... you GO COVE!
author: Randy M.

description:
Can't say enough good things about The Cove. Their staff- all of them- are sweet, smart, and nice to look at.  Their food always rocks, especially the chicken fried steak. Their side salad is more than an afterthought- full of fresh veggies and they make the good kind of ranch dressing. I think about the ranch dressing sometimes at night. 

I love the videos and pictures they show. Makes me feel somehow gayer and that is a good thing. 

Please eat here as much as possible during the Castro Street renovations because I love this place and I don't want all of the chaos out there to dent their business!

These people are not paying me, promise. Now how can I buy one of their Cove tee shirts?
author: Austin M.

description: Good spot for bkfst ,fast service ,healthy good and located right in front of Castro theater . A good way to start your day
author: David M.

description: I've always been very critical of this place, saying that it's just a basic diner...no biggie, whatever ho hum.   Recently, I went in here for breakfast and was blown away at what I ate.  I feel like my stubbornness has me making up for lost time now.   I ordered the Smoked Trout Benedict ($14).  I was blown away at how good it was!  The trout was smokey and juicy, the hollandaise sauce was on point!   Service was prompt and friendly as well.
author: Matt V.

description:
By far one of the best restaurants in the Castro. Not only is the staff an incredible bunch of people, but the food is absolutely delicious!

I mean, they have tots!

I feel like a part of the Cove family every time I'm here for brunch on the weekends. And those bottomless mimosas make the experience that much more entertaining. Nathan really understands the concept of not finding the bottom of your glass, and the owner, or "mama" as some people call her, is one of the most darling people I have had the pleasure to meet. Make sure you stop by and grab a bite even during the construction on Castro.
author: Richard M.

description:
Started off my date day with my partner there today. Friendly staff. Lively place. Castro at its best. But the food was absolutely bad. I had two eggs with a turkey sausage patty. It came burned on the outside and soft and wet on the inside. I had two bites and my mind said stop. 

I told one of the managers and she was super nice and said she won't charge me. That's good service, well the bill came and the charge was there. I decided to not make a fuss. I should have. 

I threw up 10 minutes after I left the restaurant. 

I will not go back, please get the food fixed.
author: Ulrich L.

description:
I've gone there for almost 20 years, and every time I leave I do not return for about 3 years. I always remember the food was ok, but I do recall the prices were high for what you get. I recently went again, and now I remember why my visits there are so sporadic.

I've only got one thing to say, and this is why I'll never return. I ordered pancakes, and they do not come with syrup. If you want maple syrup, it costs an additional $2.50 for a side of syrup. Are you kidding me??? This is outrageous!

Better off going to Orphan Andy's right around the corner on 19th street. It's pretty much the same food, however you are not price gouged.
author: J M.

description: This was a case of being very hungry, and needing to eat NOW! We walked past initially, then our stomachs said "STOP, and look at the menu" the prices were reasonable, and the food was great! I had the Chicken Marsala, and my girlfriend had the Chicken fried Steak. Both were tender and flavorful, the mashed potatoes were good, as was the vegetables, which were a fresh broccoli, cauliflower and carrot medley,the veggies were tender, and perfectly al dente. We split dessert, which was the chocolate tuxedo cake, just sweet enough, it was very good, a perfect end to our meal.
author: Tracy D.

description:
Sigh.. What happened with Cafe Cove? The last time I went to Cafe Cove was 3 years ago, and I have been going there since 1990's   They have raised prices, made breakfast/brunch portions much smaller and less delicious.   What a joke!   I am really disappointed with the food. The coffee costs $3 and is not really good too (I should have went to Peets and grabbed one for $2). 

I ordered "Cove Combo" which was 1/2 waffle, eggs, and sausages.  When they brought it, sausages were really small, and eggs were simply cooked, and waffle, well..was obviously frozen.. For 12 dollars.  Sigh... 

Not worth it.

I miss the old Cove in 90s when the food was really fresh and good and cheaper.

My partner ordered omelet that did not come wit hbread.  If you want bread, you cough up $2 more. Really???

bye bye cove... i used to respect you, but not anymore.
author: vadim m.

description:
Endangered species.

Save the dolphins: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Cove_(film)

Save your hunger: Homemade turkey burger with special seasonings and egg. Texture is a bit like meatloaf. Taste is unique and delicious. Massive side salad as well.

Then save it again: Breakfast special with grilled chicken, cottage cheese, egg whites, spinach and tomato. Loved. Same goes for the crunchy and sweet homemade granola.

Service is the opposite of those heartless Japanese fishermen. Friendly. Warm. Welcoming. Small granola side was complimentary. Free WiFi troubles solved.

Grab one of the seats near the window for a view of life on Castro Street.

Prices are a little high ($12 - $16 for each includes tax/generous tip) but the quality of the food and staff make it worth every penny.

First Cove is most important. Second Cove is most enjoyable.
author: Jason B.

description: Nice small place. I was seated right away. The waiters were nice and awesome. I got the meatloaf and a coke. I was served fast after I ordered and my drink kept getting refill. I'm happy if I'm ever back in SF I will definitely comeback.
author: Jim V.

description:
Great staff (!!!) and good food. Had brunch and late lunch here. Fish with the fish & chips were great, and red snapper rather than cod. Well prepared. Rest of food was good as well.

That was four years ago.

It's continued to be good to the present. Much of the staff continues, and while they've got a different cook (due to tragedy), the newer cook has come along nicely.

I am a regular here, and continue to enjoy it.
author: R H.

description:
They have a knack of treating my husband and I like we've been living in the neighborhood for years.

Breakfast happens to be my favorite time of the day to come. Their food is diner quality but it's the service that puts this place over the top for me.

What more can I say?
author: Steven G.

description: My favorite thing about this place here is its employees and owners. They're very friendly. And there's a very cute blondish server boy, I love him. Food is very good, many options. It comes fast and satisfies!
author: Çağlar A.

description: My first visit here was on Thanksgiving day. I used to do a pilgrimage to Castro Tart, but the Vietnamese couple is finally Americanized and closed this year on Thanksgiving. I stumbled on the Cove (which has been there, literally, for years) and was very pleasantly surprised with the chicken fried steak. So surprised that I anxiously went back for the biscuits and gravy. Mistake.  Not sure if it was a lucky day or what, but the second visit was to a tired old diner that is way past its prime with less-than-mediocre food. Sorry, Cove, the thrill was short-lived.
author: Robert M.

description: I bought a chicken noodle soup from this place to take out. Cost 14$ for a big bowl 0_0. I am experiencing some stomach issues and I was hoping to get something like 'homemade' comfy  food. The soup I bought at this place could not ever be called homemade - my mouth was burning from how salty it it. INSANLY SALTY.  My husband also said it's too much salt. The stuff on the phone was very rude, they claimed the soup is just fine, but I could bring it back and they would refund me. All that said in not friendly, arrogant way. They were not sorry that my lunch was spoiled. I was already back at my place on a steep hill and didn't have time to return it. Never go there again.
author: Masha K.

description: I wanted to add that they do bottomless mimosas EVERYDAY :) with purchase of food for $14.95 till 4pm. And they are on it with the quick refills! Great customer service and great tasting food :). Everyone who works there is amazing and so friendly.
author: Tracy B.

description: The Cove is a really unique place to eat in the Castro. My experience here was perfect! I love the ambiance here- the lamp lighting, window seats with colored pillows, it's just too cute. And, Our server was so sweet! He helped me find something on the menu when I wasn't sure what to order, and he came back to our table the perfect amount of time when we needed him to- not too little or too much. I suggest going here for a relaxing dinner with someone special.
author: Jade M.

description: From the perspective of a pleasant dining experience, there's absolutely nothing wrong with this place.
author: Wyatt B.

description:
The Cove sounds like the name of a bar in the Castro...dark, wet, leathery and full of...uhhh...spunky spelunkers. But no, it's just a neighborhood place to eat a pancake or pick up a salad. Well, I guess unless you want to bring your flashlight and a lot of rope.

And it has the unwieldy pressure of having to serve us big-bellied breakfast eaters hankering for the domestic cholesterol-saturated bliss that was Welcome Home. With the untimely passing of that establishment last year, one must either come here or compete with the voracious trannies at Orphan Andy's.

Alas, I may have to shave my legs now. Now don't get me wrong. The fellas here are super-friendly in an unforced way. They make me feel like a relative who doesn't owe them money. But the food is, well...just not the home cooking I keep hoping they would have. I came in for breakfast and had one of their daily specials, the $8.95 California Benedict, which was Eggs Benedict but using their turkey hash instead of Canadian bacon. I just though the English muffins were a tad overtoasted and the combination of poached eggs and hash made it soggier than I was expecting.

Oh, I ate it all...but the food was sticking to my ribs like Britney Spears' radial tire to a paparazzo's foot. On the upside, the hash browns were tasty, especially with a liberal dousing of hot sauce. But I have to tell you that regulars came in and out and were greeted warmly by the staff. So who can complain too much about a place that brings a touch of Mayberry to a 'hood full of brotherly (and sisterly) love?

FOOD - 3 stars...not the best Benedict, but that doesn't make me a Benedict Arnold, does it?
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...low-key and suburban-feeling...except for the flashes of semi-clad beefcake to be found on the TV screens above
SERVICE - 4 stars...friendly like Goober and Emmett and Barney and Andy....if they were all in a hot tub together
TOTAL - 3 stars...food needs work but not the good spirit around here
author: Ed U.

description: A few years ago, we stumbled across this restaurant when looking for a place to eat on Thanksgiving. Turns out, they have a huge and awesome Thanksgiving meal for a totally reasonable price. We've gone three years in a row. The food (and creative soups!) are great! The servers are always sassy and witty, which is fun. The food is served quickly. This iconic Castro diner is a great establishment that I hope to keep visiting over the years. It wouldn't be a Tripp SF without it!
author: Daniel C.

description:
Another lovely Castro joint that doesn't require an unnecessarily long wait. (Fork Cafe is the other one, in case you're wondering, http://www.yelp.com/biz/fork-cafe-san-francisco#hrid:XlY0YhE8LbCze7vaNe_aSA.)

Walked right in on a Saturday morning and seated ourselves at at the comfiest-looking booth. The place is strewn with regulars who excitedly greet and air-kiss (what looks like) the owner. As soon as we sat down, menus were offered and drink orders were taken.

DRINK
+Coffee: diner coffee; so, not the best. If you are looking for a tasty cup, head down to Philz a few blocks down.
+Orange juice: fresh-squeezed and served in a frosty glass mug. Classy!
+Water: served upon request.
(Decided to forgo bottomless mimosas thanks to the Bisou debacle a few weeks prior, http://www.yelp.com/biz/bisou-san-francisco#hrid:nSn5r75XB8JCO-27ijLJnw)

EAT
+Croissant special: eggs cooked your way (I got 'em over-medium) with Gruyere cheese in a buttery croissant, served with a side of fruit. Tasty and surprisingly filling.
+2-2-2: two eggs, two slices of bacon (thick, long, tasty... ahem), two slices of French toast. They messed up the order and brought over two pancakes, but there were no complaints.

Decent prices, good service, chain-style diner food without the latent guilt of supporting a chain.
author: Adena B.

description: Wow !! Thank you solange!! It's nice to be cared about. You and the entire team really go out of the way to make your guest know they are family not just $$.. Thanks for maligning a rough week more easy!
author: Jason P.

description:
This is a downright homey place that I gladly come for breakfast.  Fork is more expensive and the food didn't reflect that.  I like the diner feel of the cove with traditional breakfast choices.  Our waiter was on his first day on the job and a slightly sweaty and flustered which was a bit endearing actually.  He was grateful to have the job and did everything he could to make us happy.

There's something neighborhood like about Cove that just makes you feel like you belong here.  I had the 2-2-2 and it was perfect.  I didn't even get a chance to snag food off my fellow diners' plates because they cleaned up their plates.  I really wanted some hashbrowns.  

Also, what legit establishment in the Castro doesn't have a TV.  I mean seriously...

The staff is accommodating, friendly, and this place is just a charming diner without the fancy bells and whistles that I would come to again and again.
author: Christina C.

description: We are very lucky to have this "comfort of home" place to eat in the Castro.  Today I stopped in with my partner and son for a before Christmas lunch.  After 10 years, Solange knows me and greets me with a hug.  Scott the waiter is always so pleased to see us and also gave a wonderful hug for me, my partner and my son.  Solange, Scott, Annie, and the rest have watched my son grow up at their tables.  From the newborn I sat on the table, the toddler who could walk under the table,  and now the 10 year old who doesn't need his menu to order.   This is not the fancy french restaurant or the new trendy spot, but it is our tradition.  The place my son thinks about as where he and Dad go to eat.   The place that serves his favorite french toast with eggs and bacon with the fresh squeezed orange juice.  An order Scott always remembers.  It is my place for tomatoe soup and a toasted cheese.  The best shredded potatoes for breakfast.  I always crumble my bacon into them and add some hot sauce.   So over 10+ years later (yes before my son was born I would go),  I still find this place to be my "comforts of home" environment.  Wonderful comfort foods with a family friendly and familiar staff.   Thank you Solange and your staff for making this an irreplaceable tradition for us.
author: James W.

description: Always great service and food. Every time we are in there is packed but the staff always seats you in an expedient fashion. The prices for breakfast are very reasonable and bottomless mimosas for $14 and they let you drink at least 14 of them. If your in the Castro this is the place for breakfast.
author: Jason R.

description:
Today was my friends birthday and I decided to take him to The Cove for lunch.  About a week ago, I stopped by to speak with Salange to ask about bringing a cake.  She suggested that she get it and of course I said yes.  She and the entire staff pulled out all the stops and made such a fuss even getting the others to sing Happy Birthday.

Once again, she showed how warm and kind and truly caring she is and how much she really does care about the community.

Salange, you'll always have a special place in my heart, the hearts of all of my friends and the hearts of anyone that has been enjoying your hospitality through the years.

Simply put...The Cove is...FABULOUS...
author: Phoenix B.

description: Not only is the food great, but the service just makes the experience ten times better. Looking forward to coming here when I can.
author: Mike B.

description: Felt like a real neighborhood establishment. Food of ok quality. It had a strange atmosphere to it and kind of a backward layout. Have only been there once. Would not go out of my way to go back.
author: David H.

description:
I love The Cove. Why? Because they serve a good patty melt and their fry cook knows how to get the onion rings and fries crispy. Not only that, but they have the perfect breakfast combo: The Cove Combo - 2 eggs, bacon or sausage, and half a belgian waffle. Add strawberries to the waffle and hash browns on the the side for the perfect breakfast. A little bit of everything.

Upside: love the neighborhood feel, lots of regulars and the staff is friendly
Downside: gets busy on the weekends, so sometimes you have to wait a few - but that's to be expected.
author: Amy S.

description: Miss your moms cooking? Come here. Comfort food at a great price! The staff is great, funny and efficient. Their daily/nightly are great, they are one or two steps above the regular menu items. They have been family owned since 1972 and Solange and Maurice have been running it since the mid 80's. A true gem in the Castro !
author: Kevin l.

description: So happy this comfortable Castro diner is still here.  I try to drop in whenever in San Francisco.  Nothing crazy unique here... Good diner food, with a lot of local flavor to entertain you while you eat.  The service and staff is friendly... Feels like they've known you for years!  I usually have breakfast here...solid amercian diner choices...all good.  Enjoy it when you are walking the Castro....
author: Patrick B.

description:
I ordered a mimosa. It was 9am on a Saturday. "Are you sure you don't want an endless one?" I looked at the Tupperware bottle that contained the decarbonated pulpy mimosa that looked like a far leap from celebratory. I shook my head. "You can always change your mind later."

I'll never change my mind. I will also never come back here.

It was a week after New Years Day and the Christmas decorations were still up. The curtains near the window are caked in dust. And could you turn up the Rihanna so I don't have to hear about the guy next to me and his epic hangover?
author: Peter H.

description:
The buckwheat pancakes here are completely amazing. Okay, while they might just be pancakes made out of buckwheat, there aren't many places that have this, PLUS they have that sweet, natural, real maple syrup. There's something magical in the morning when you get taken back to childhood with every bite.

Scott is an amazing waiter. I think he's originally from Memphis, and still has that wonderful southern charm. If you're in the neighborhood and are looking for a no frills diner/cafe, that has great food, I'd definitely consider the Cove :)
author: Nicholas L.

description:
Dear Cove,

Your staff were charming and efficient and friendly. I was craving a good solid breakfast on my birthday. It took a lot to persuade my breakfast-food-averse husband to play along but hey, it's my birthday. He obliged. 

The bacon was crispy and perfectly done. The over easy egg the same. 

But when I order blueberry pancakes, I do not want plain pancakes with a jar of blueberry preserves dumped over them. That's just plain lazy.
author: Ben D.

description: My favorite local place for breakfast.  Real hash browns!  Great food, reasonable prices.  What San Francisco used to be like -- neighborhood mom and pop restaurants with real home cooking.  If you want to eat like a local whose been here awhile, go to the Cove
author: Ken W.

description:
A surprising little find!  I was having my car smogged across the street (BTW, highly recommend!  -Castro Street Smog-Good price, guy there was nice enough (hey-he's not paid to be the social creature that others of us are...)-but I guess I need to reserve that review for another time!

So I go there with my kid who needed to do his homework.  It was off-hours, so plenty of seating where he could spread out with his books.  I will admit-I had ONION RINGS, which were done RIGHT!  Not breaded, but battered; nice and crispy!  I also ordered their black bean soup that was absolutely deeee-lish and hit the spot on a cold day.  They always have three soups on their menu-all homemade and (as I understand it), always one vegan option.

I'm not in this area all the time-as with many areas in the City, parking can suck but is surprisingly easy on off-hours.  Of course, very reachable via public transit as it is right off of Market Street!

Oh...just to mention.  My 11 yo was with me and you have to remember you are in the CASTRO.  That said, there are televisions placed around the cafe with little slideshows of barechested men, men kissing men, women and men kissing.  I didn't care-it's a cultural thing for my kid and I knew where I was at.  If this is a problem for you, then you need to note this.  Granted, my kid looked up and said, 'Eeeewwww...' --more of a reaction to barechested men and 'kissing' pictures, which would not be uncommon for his age anyway.  Kissing is icky at 11 yo!
author: Leslie W.

description: Philly cheesesteak and french toast were on point!! 10 stars for the bottomless mimosas made with FRESH orange juice!! 1st timers will definitely be back again!! Service was extremely good too our server was Diego he was the sweetest person I have ever met!!
author: claudia a.

description: The food was really fresh and tasty.  The place was very quaint.  The waitstaff was pleasant.  I was there touring San Francisco, but don't like doing touristy things.  I thought this place had a real warm hometown feel to it.  Hope to visit again!
author: Shannon S.

description: Nothing says quality like receiving your dinner with mashed potato that were obviously plated hours ago. Like a thick hard crust formed over them.
author: Shawn C.

description:
Seriously the best place for that "home cooked" kind of grub.  Service is always super friendly, prices are reasonable and I've yet to have a bad meal at this place.  

Breakfast is what they do best, but the lunch/dinner dishes are great too.  

Oh yeah, it's definitely a casual place with a welcoming atmosphere for all, not just the gay guys.  So make this your next late Sunday morning venture.
author: Edward H.

description:
Everything here is great. I've been there for breakfast, lunch, brunch, dinner, dessert with friends and it's all been great.

Awesome service and I love to be able to sit at the window seating and watch the Castro go by.
author: Tom M.

description: I cannot review the food as I was not able to eat there. The moment i walked in, i was assaulted with the smell that can only be best described as body odor. However this odor was not due to a customer, but from walls of the restaurant itself. I could only take it for a moment then had to leave.
author: Gregory W.

description: Sadly, I was unimpressed. Sweet server; underwhelming food. Orphan Andy's chicken fried steak wins by TKO.
author: Pollo D.

description:
Waffles, strawberries and chocolate nutella. Amaaaaaazing!

The service here are always sweethearts and very attentive. The menu is great and I have never been disappointed. I always bring my friends from out of town or state here when they visit because of how unpretentious and welcoming the atmosphere is. It definitely would make Harvey Milk proud than the bitchy stereotypes that serve at that gnat infested Harvey's down the street capitalizing on his image. That's why The Cove is one of the very few humble places I enjoy here in the Castro when everything else here seems to cater to the tourism.
author: Terry C.

description:
A friend of mine who is  a regular here brought me for a weekday lunch. It's a no frills, neighborhood diner where the waitstaff is friendly and makes you feel like you've been there before. There is a huge menu with  lot of selection, which personally confused me. So I did what any confused diner does - I asked the staff. Our server pointed me towards the Thai red curry and it was delicious! Spicy, slightly sweet and the perfect balance of flavors. I would never have guess it came from a diner. My friend ordered the mac and cheese which was divine. It was perfectly cheesey (not overwhelming) with salty bread crumbs baked on top. And I loved the presentation with two slices of cheese melted right on top. Delish!

For more vegetarian reviews, check out: www.veggiewala.com
author: Jesal P.

description: I like the atmosphere, but I've always found the service lacking. And the prices are extremely high for the bland quality. Nothing to come back for. I've been in probably a dozen times over the past twenty years, and never that great. Always get suckered in by friends who like it. :)
author: Zann G.

description: The Cove on Castro has an old diner feel and is need of a facelift.  The food is decent - regular breakfast and lunch fare with omelettes, waffles, and sandwiches - and service is friendly but our meal took forever to come to us.  Wander over to Orphan Andy's if you want a slightly prettier environment.  Go to Harvey's for a more class.
author: Chad S.

description:
7-11-09
I had breakfast here again and had another good experience.  I had the cove omelette and it was awesome.  It had salsa, sour cream, and lots of avocado on top.  It was so good.  Take a look at the pic I posted on the cove omelette.
author: Kare V.

description: The Cove is a great place to grab a decent breakfast or lunch with friends in the Castro. Nice friendly hometown service, and good diner food paired with fun patrons. Makes for a great way to start the day.
author: Greg S.

description:
Eggs Benedict: I, Eggs Benedict, take you, Corned Beef Hash, to be my wedded husband. To have and to lay on, from this day forward, for better, for spicier, in healthy appetite, to love and to cherish 'till someone eats us up. And hereto I pledge you my faithfulness.

Corned Beef Hash: I, Corned Beef Hash, take you, Eggs Benedict, to be my wedded husband. To have and to lay on on me, from this day forward, for yummy, for creamier, in healthy appetite, to love and to cherish 'till someone eats us up. And hereto I pledge you my faithfulness.

Cove on the Castro: I now pronounce you, Irish Benedict.

Okay, that was pretty cheesy. Seriously though, if you love corned beef hash and eggs benedict like me, you're probably quite turned on right now. The Irish Benedict is not on their regular menu, but they seem to always have it as a special on the weekends. Get there early because people love their corned beef hash. 

Generally, Cove on the Castro is your best bet for fabulous, generously portioned breakfasts in the Castro. The lunch plates I've seen look quite full as well and they have homemade soups (Chix noodle always for the sickies). The service is very friendly, but can feel slow if you're not in the mood for leisure. I've chosen the Cove as my default diner when I don't feel like making the trek out of the neighborhood. Not outstanding in terms of flavors, but solid.
author: Rina W.

description:
Three words - Worse service ever!

My friends and I are never stepping foot into the Cove again.
Three of us went there on a Sunday for Brunch and waited...and waited..and waited for our food.  I timed it and 40 minutes passed from the time we sat down to when they brought out our food.  I understand that it was crowded, but I don't think any other table had to wait as long.  We saw customers who entered maybe half an hour after us, and they were able to get their food right after we got ours.  

In fact, we waited so long, that one out of the three of us had to leave to get to work.  He was gonna call to join us when the food arrived or to just have us bag it for him.  So my remaining friend and I had our breakfast and the waiter said that he'd put the third order under the heat lamp to keep it warm. Now this is the part that ticked me off.  Rather than packing up the third order in a box, they threw it out.  Yet when the check came, we were still charged for it!!!

Lets just say that I would have popped a vein if my friend didn't hold me back.  I understand charging us for the food since our friend did order it before he left, but why throw it out rather than bagging it for us?  Does that make any logical sense whatsoever???  We asked to talk to the manager, and they said that they would remake the order for us.  Yea right, no thanks...we waited 40 minutes the first time, we didn't want to spend the rest of our afternoon in that place.  The manager finally agreed to deduct the food from the bill that they had thrown out without asking.  

Well, this place does have the distinction of being the only meal at a sit down restaurant that my friend refused to tip at. Good job there!

P.S. I guess I should mention something about the food since this is a yelp review...  The portions are pretty small for the relatively high price that you pay.  The eggs and sausages that I got were tiny.
author: Tyler C.

description: Decided to give this place a try for a chilly Saturday brunch. Reasonably priced food. Had the Louisiana Benedict. My one "complaint" is that the eggs weren't poached quite long enough, but that didn't stop me from devouring it all!  Reasonable portion size means no wasted food--I like that I don't feel overfull. Temperature inside was very toasty but on a cool day I didn't mind. Wonderful host/waiter, very welcoming. Happy to see this place was hopping despite the heinous sidewalk construction on Castro. I will DEFINITELY return!!
author: Scott T.

description: I've been eating at The Cove since the 90's and there is always a crowd of regulars there having lunch. This afternoon there was a group of "very young" drunk kids being loud and obnoxious to the point they were disturbing other patrons. My friend and I decided to leave since the staff wasn't doing anything about it and seemed to be serving them more mimosa's. If that is The Coves new policy to allow a table of five obvious underage kids drink and act like fools while they stand around doing nothing then I'll be going elsewhere from now on.
author: Robert O.

description:
Every neighborhood needs a Cove.

A friendly, familiar place with good, basic food at reasonable prices. The kind of place where you can roll out of bed on a Sunday morning, rub the sleep out of your eyes, throw on whatever's clean and walk over for some eggs benedict and coffee.

The kid and I were there Saturday afternoon and shared a cheeseburger and fries. Between the two of us there were still leftovers, so don't let your eyes be bigger than your stomach by overordering. Food and drink (apple juice for the kid and a glass of house red for mommy) came to $18 and change.

Drop in sometime if you happen to be in the neighborhood!
author: Valeria R.

description: I love The Cove on Castro. I eat breakfast there almost every Sunday. It is my first choice. They make custom egg scrambles or omelets, they are fast and very courteous. Their food is good quality and the coffee is very good as well. Try it - I think you'll like it!
author: Joanne F.

description:
My local go to eating hole.  I am a very picky eater, can be obnoxious about it, but somehow at The Cove I just don't care.  It's the ambiance and the wait staff that makes the place and that's why I frequent it.  

The food is nothing out of this world, it is a dinner, however not on the greasy side which is a good thing.  The bread ROCKS and it's home made. The salads are also very good and very BIG.  They have the best turkey burger I've ever had.  The turkey meal is deliciously homely. It's comfort food sometimes you crave.  Oh!  The curly fries, yummy!! Spicey and curly, no ketchup needed.  Sometimes you just gotta have something starchy and fried.

Strongly recommend if you're seeking comfort via your belly.
author: Pavarti B.

description: If you know what to order you can have a great meal. Sick to the specials and talk to your waiter, they are adorable and supper friendly. I've never had a waiter there steer me wrong and I've always found interesting conversation with whomever i'm sitting near.
author: Katerina M.

description:
Got the BEST Reuben sandwhich I ever ate.  It was a "vege" sandwich too and I didn't miss the corn beef one bit!  Great service and enjoyed the relaxed Sunday atmosphere.   Only thing that didn't agree with me is that I'm a gal and had to share a bathroom with the guys....  I'm a little funny that way, but that's me....  
Hugs.
author: Doris D.

description: Friendly and cozy.  Decent food and value.
author: Geoff L.

description: I had a lovely lunch here today. My servers were especially friendly and attentive. The food I had was great (I had the falafel) and I enjoyed the ambiance as it felt like a cozy community-oriented space where everyone seemed to know each other. I will definitely be back.
author: Storm A.

description:
A perfectly adequate, greasy American breakfast in copious quantities.  It's a bit like a New Jersey diner in food only without the 25 page menu.  I came here for a New Year's Day brunch, craving greasy food to cure my hangover.  This place delivered with friendly service.  The food does nothing to stand out in a good or bad way.  The hash browns though were a bit odd...a giant mass that was cooked on the outside, but not really on the inside.

Summary: average food, quick, large quantities, friendly service, convenient location.
author: Ian P.

description: Was in Castro w/ my roomate and was asked.....WHERE do you want to go to lunch?  I immediately insisted on coming here!  Cove On Castro that is..... My past experience w/ them since 1999 has been positive and versus other places that I am not gonna name thats next to Walgreens...  Cove has served good food, not so bad service and fair prices.  And they have Wi-Fi!   Weekends, the Cove does have a high traffic of patrons so make the best of seats that are available.
author: Jake M.

description:
TWO WORDS:  BOTTOMLESS MIMOSAS.

Oh, and I am now a huge fan of the andouli sausage eggs benedict (order extra hollandaise sauce) plate which is brilliant!
author: Sam A.

description:
Good food.  It's comfort food for me...a former Midwesterner.  
They have breakfast, lunch and dinner...:-)  I like it all...just depends on my mood.

Good service.  Sassy, yes but still they're friendly!!  It's a freakin' diner feel...deal with it.  If not, get out!

Great molasses cookies--never had it before this place!

Just a good time, that is close to my neighborhood!
author: Fannie S.

description:
The food is great classic American Cafe food for breakfast, lunch and dinner.  

A wonderful surprise is their Monte Christo sandwich.  They prepare it in the classic manner where the ham, turkey and cheese sandwich is dipped in egg batter and fried in oil.  It is very rich but worth the extra calories.  

Few places still make this meal the classic way and instead just take French toast and add some cheese and ham between it.  

They only offer this meal one or two days a week but everything else on their menu is just perfect too!
author: Kevin C.

description: No better place to eat on Castro Street. Where all the locals gather for a good affordable meal.
author: Ken I.

description: It's a neighborly cafe with decent food. I find restrooms in SF restaurants horrifying but this is no worse than the others in this neighborhood. Out front it seems clean, well run, and a place where many folks know one another.
author: Jim G.

description:
It isn't elegant, but it is good stick to your ribs fare. I love this place, I had to rate them down because quality has slipped, but some sure hits...

1. Fresh Turkey Sandwich, old school and good.
2. Tomato Bisque, a main and it is damn good.
3. Fish & Chips, they are always really tasty.  

The Cove is a classic diner, the staff are attentive and good.  I appreicate this place for being a little slice of home.
author: Troy C.

description:
Real sliced turkey in the club sandwiches they serve!

Annie our server is da BOMB!
author: Dave M.

description:
My friends and I are here almost every weekend. They have endless Mimosas with real ingredients, awesome staff and delicious food. My favorite is the Irish Benedict. The Cove is a neighborhood staple. Most of the time you can find the owner, Solange, in the thick of it, helping make sure everyone is having a good time.

When one of their servers came down with breast cancer, they held a fundraiser to help with her expenses. The entire crew pitched in, singing, playing the piano and doing comedy. It made me proud to be associated with them.
author: Eric M.

description:
So I feel it is my duty to save everyone from having to try out this place. The customer service was ok. The guy was clearly over it and to be frank if I were a 50 year old waiter I would be too. He was ok I wasnt expecting him to be excited so he wasnt rude or anything like that. 

The food? yeah not so much. The fruit salad was melon wedges pineapple and I single orange slice. I need to point out the the orange was dry like literally the whites of it were shriveled up. Ok so the fruit clearly was old. We asked them to take that off the bill and they did thank god. The eggs Benedict was awful! The hollandaise sauce was not only cold it tasted very odd I honestly think it was stale. The hash browns were very bland also. With all the businesses folding in the Castro I am shocked this place is still left standing. I will not be going back. If you read this and eat there do so at your own risk you were warned.
author: Mike R.

description:
I've been eating at the Cove for close to ten years, some times every night for weeks at a time.  I eat breakfast, lunch or dinner there regularly, though less often since I became an Unemployed Dragon.  

The food is good, basic, hearty diner food.  I love their soups and grilled sandwiches especially.  I used to eat full dinners more often and I love their Chicken Marsala and their Macaroni and Cheese. 

The staff is so friendly and welcoming. Everyone seems happy to be working there.  I've always had the sense that the owners are very good to them.  

The Coves' prices are high, but I'm happy to patronize a local business that has been in the Castro for a long time and that treats its staff well, and that is so welcoming.
author: Unemployed D.

description:
Went there a couple times a long time ago and they pictures of gay men all over the walls...everywhere.  i thought it was pretty cool.  I don't recall how the food was.

The third  time I went there they served me a drink in a very dirty glass.  I thought the gay guys working there hated me because I am a woman and a lesbian so I didn't go back for a couple years.  I was pissed.

Then people kept telling me how good the Cove is.  I decided to go back and give it another try.  Probably new employees in there by now.  So I went inside and I was seated and no more photos on the walls.  Now they had some widescreen TVs on the walls and the photos were shown in a slow slideshow on those screens.  Kind of looks lame because the photos don't fill up the screen.  I liked it the old way.

Anyways, food was good, drnks were good.  And i have been going back there now and then and nothing but good food and good experiences.  I am even casual friends with two people who work there..  One lesbian and one gay Latino boy who is fluent in Spanish and not so fluent in English..

Anyways, so far so good.  They serve alcohol drinks, so keep that in mind if you want a bloody mary with your breakfast.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
Pricey, which is why I can't go that often. But they do have a very good breakfast special if you plan on getting in there early. 

Because my sweetheart was sick and it pained me to hear her cough stuff up, I was taking her to breakfast as a treat before going to the doctor. Of course we didn't get there early for breakfast specials and so we stuck with the 2-2-2 deal, which was the only thing on the menu that wasn't $11. Tea was $2.75. 

I do understand why the food is worth the price. Their scrambled eggs are *perfect* and their fruit cup is not at all skimpy and has more than just melon in it, and the fruit is actually ripe and fresh.

The staff is crazy nice - when I asked, our waiter put my darling's tea in a to-go cup for us and topped it off with more hot water. Thanks for the much-needed extra attention!

The ambiance, with the wooden chairs, old-timey mo-town, disco and doo-appy sounds and screen that tells you who you're listening to, as well as the little tables everywhere, reminds me of the Lakeview/Boystown neighborhood breakfast places in Chicago.
author: Josephine L.

description:
Service is 6 stars out of 5!

The homemade food there is very good. I shared tomato soup, it was awesome. 

Had tilapia, fish & vegetables were fresh and really delicious but brown rice was bit stale, still good flavor (maybe ask to substitute rice w/ something else?).

Had chocolate torte, it was just ok. (Its not made there, so I'd stick w/ things they make in house).

Nice quiet place. Comfortable and clean too, the team paid great attention to us.

OH btw, servings are HUGE.
Special on Sunday between 4 - 6:30 where you can add soup & drink/desert to your entree for $4 but all that is enough food for almost 2 people (if you upgrade the soup to a bowl).
author: Grilled O.

description:
So you want a reasonably priced meal at a joint with a low-key vibe? Well, I can recommend quite a few others far better than the Cove. 

It seems most review The Cove for breakfast or lunch, so perhaps I made the mistake in going there for dinner. I paid $20 (including tip- and it was a less than $2 tip, yes...you'll see why) for a bowl of soup, a slice of bread, two glasses of wine and a plate of veggies. Ok, so for $20 that's not bad. However the food and service were mediocre.

VEGAN LENTIL SOUP- not enough hearty lentils! I've made much better at home. It came with a slice of their "house made" irish soda bread, but if you ask me that bread was store bought yesterday and sliced too thin. Ever have soda bread at The Phoenix?!!? I was expecting it to be more like that....or at least warmed up.

VEGETABLES- thankfully it was a large portion of broccoli, cauliflower, and carrots (as most places skimp on side orders of veggies), but they were cooked with just a bit too much butter. If they'd buttered it up by even 1/4 a teaspoon more I would think I was having Denny's diner style veggies (Or Lucky Penny, anyone?). Hmm...yeah.

And as for the service... I was eyeing the corner table next to the window, as it seemed more cozy and is semi blocked off by the entry drapes. When the patron sitting there left, I looked to the waiter to make sure it was okay to move.
