He didn't seem too enthusiastic about having to clean up the table so quickly, so I gave him a few minutes to clear it and started to move my things. As I was doing so, he brought food to my old table and my suspicion was confirmed as he didn't even offer to help me relocate my utensils, beverage, or either of the two plates and bowl with me. Might I add, I was one of about 6 people there. 

No need to try it again.
author: Raquel C.

description: Great local breakfast. The San Francisco Benedict was scrumptious. The service friendly. Derick was a great waiter.
author: Susan M.

description:
Stopped in here while waiting on a scrip @ Walgreens. More of a diner than a cafe.

Service was quick and polite. My breakfast was good, if unremarkable standard American fare. The coffee was also pretty standard, but they did offer to refill it at least half a dozen times. 

If you need a quick, basic, but solid meal, stop on by.
author: Erich N.

description: Great service, great all American food, great atmosphere. What else do you need? For me, a Saturday afternoon with my gays is the way to go!
author: Stephanie W.

description: My parents love this place. The breakfasts are consistent, if you want the standards with friendly service Cove is a good place to go.
author: Alison F.

description:
Comfort Food is what they say is the centering theme of this diner-style eatery. I had the shepherds pie while my dining companion had the fish and chips.  Overall, the food is straightforward.  The Shepherd's pie was delicious.  My only criticism was that I felt the portions where a little on the smallish side and the soda was flat.

Servers are polite and attentive for the most part.  I would eat here again if I wanted to get a quick diner-style meal on my way to a beer bust next door at 440 Bar. The Cove Cafe is simple, nothing fancy, and nothing to really rave about (but then again, there are really few food places in the Castro that anyone could really rave about).
author: Alex D.

description: I have been going here for breakfast on and off for about a year. The food has always been good and the wait staff has always been very pleasant but sometimes fails to deliver good customer service when they are busy. I had Easter Breakfast at The Cove and had a wonderful experience with the service and as always my food was very good. I had one of my favorites waffle, eggs and well done bacon! It was yummy. The Easter Bunnies were wonderful and gave a nice Easter feel!  I would defiantly recommend breakfast here but be warned it can get very busy on the weekends.
author: Russell D.

description: Went here for lunch when we were out sightseeing. A man handing out brochures about sites in Castro recommended Cove. The food was delicious and the service was superb. I had a veggie sandwich with goat cheese and tomato soup. My daughter had a grilled cheese and my son had a beef au jus sandwich. Everything was fresh and homemade. The server was delightful. She was very welcoming and friendly. If you are in the area, it's definitely worth stopping in for a meal.
author: Karen A.

description: Went here while I was visiting SF on a road trip with my friend. We were walking in the Castro and just randomly stopped in to grab something to eat. I think the location is wonderful, the staff was incredibly friendly, and the food was great. A great (not surprisingly) LGBT-friendly cafe style restaurant. Medium price range depending on what you call cheap. In my opinion, pretty decent value for the food. I ordered a falafel  and it came with this little cucumber salad that had DELICIOUS dressing. Loved it.
author: Hannah J.

description: Wonderful wonderful place, everyone is so awesome, Derrick was great constantly asking how they can help us, the six of us had well prepared  various meals and the bottomless mimosas, definitely a place to frequent when in the Castro!
author: David S.

description: This is a great place to come to eat some home made cooking.  This place has become my Breakfast spot as their breakfasts are so good and they really fill you up on the portions.   I highly recommend this place. : )
author: Rich Computer Service S.

description: Had a great lunch with hubby n kids, yummmm! The waiters are very friendly and helpful even gave my crazy son a snack while waiting for his food ;)
author: Alyssa S.

description:
Food is at best, mediocre! 
Service is worse than the food, if that's possible! 
Most of the reviews stress it's good for Breakfast....instead, hop on Muni and go to Dottie's True Blue Cafe! Now THAT's a great breakfast spot! Pay the same for in-house made fare!
author: Rebecca C.

description:
The kitchen is back up to par.  Recently, the favorite macaroni and cheese dish
was perfect.  No pepper or burned taste to it.  Keep up the good work!
author: Richard D.

description:
This little big-city cafe in the Castro has all the comforts of a good old-fashioned home-made breakfast, except you're surrounded by lots of other hungry people also looking forward to a yummy first meal of the day. 

And there's nothing fancy-schmancy about this place. If you're looking for a cool ultra-chic place to brunch, this isn't the place. But if you want a busy restaurant where you can get a hearty breakfast and where you invariably get to know everyone sitting around you.....this is the place.

And if you're lucky you'll get Anita as your server. She is by far the friendliest and most thorough person who will grant every wish you have while dining there. 

It's always fun to plan a fun weekend morning here. Breakfast at the Cove (Muni to Castro Street), then walk over to 18th Street and down to Dolores Park for the ongoing entertainment that is always happening there.
author: Mickey A.

description:
The Cove is one of my favorite places to eat in the Castro. I usually only go there for breakfast, however, last night I went there with my favorite girls Danielle and Amelia. We were exhausted and starving after having spent the past 2 hours singing our asses off in my bedroom while Danielle video taped it all (Danielle, put the damn camera down already!). 

When we got in there, it was nice to get out of the cold, and it was nice and toasty warm inside. The girls took forever to decide what to eat, even after the waitress was there taking our order, they still didn't know what they wanted and they each changed their minds once, maybe twice. Our waitress was not having it, and immediately was kind of bitchy. I hate that shit. I have never had bad service or attitude at this place, and that old bitch ruined that for me! Sooooo...I am never going there at night EVER AGAIN! Their wait-staff in the morning is superb and is always great! The food was delish. I had Shepards Pie.
author: Guy F.

description:
The Cove serves a nice turkey burger.  The service is sassy and sarcastic, and threatened spankings when I sassed back.

I could get used to this.
author: Randy F.

description: I was very happy to walk in here on labor day (Monday) and find out that they had bottomless mimosas (most places don't have that on a Monday) ... service was just ok.  Definitely a solid 3 star place.  Food is ok, not amazing, not awful.  The only reason why I'd come back here is probably for bottomless mimosas :)
author: Banana S.

description:
Straight breakfast in the Castro.

"I could take my dad here for breakfast,"  I said just as a 300lb man came walking by our window seat wearing nothing but 1970s striped, nylon "Dolphin" panties (wait, "panties" suggest some ability to contain the package - which these did not...) and combat boots.  

After finding out the hard way that 2223 and Eureka aren't open for brunch on Saturday, I decided that, given what was open and in front of us, I was in the mood for "real" breakfast instead of crepes.  The captain's Greek omlette was so perfect it looked like an advertisement for Greek omlettes.  It's a diner that doesn't feel like a greasy spoon.  The food was great, the service was attentive and they offered us a lovely table in the window on a beautiful sunny day - entertainment at no extra charge!
author: P J.

description:
It was my first time going to the Cove and I must say I was impressed with the service and most of the food.  They messed up one small thing since I ordered the salad with dressing on the side but it came with the dressing on top...oh well.  

Lots of people were already in and eating when I stopped in.  We sat ourselves and were given menus within 1 minute and asked what we wanted for drinks.  I ordered Coke and he ordered OJ.  Wow....service was fast... next time I looked up from the menu, the OJ was on the table and the Coke (glass + carafe) was there too.  The wait staff waited just long enough and took our orders.  The food (fish and chip with coleslaw & Cove club with Clam Chowder....YUM!)  came pretty quickly and they were very good about checking back in and making sure things were ok.  They called us "sweethearts and baby" which were cute...I love it when people really enjoy their jobs.  

We finished up and the bill was brought to us.  We paid and left a nice tip on the table.  I will likely to be back to try their breakfast!
author: judy l.

description: Was in the mood for breakfast and in the Castro area... we decided to check out the Cove based on a few friends' recommendations.  Its right on Castro so don't be too surprised that theres a slide show of naked men on the tv screen...  This is another of those restaurants where my foody senses go crazy- everything on the menu sounds good and everything I see on other people's tables makes me want their food...  It's kind of like an Incredible Hulk thing...  There are also plenty of smaller portions and healthier plates if you're not into the Hulk lifestyle- loser.. .  I took away 1 star because the service looks pretty hit or miss depending on who's helping you...
author: Bobby P.

description:
You can just see history dripping on its walls. Or, at least digital drops on their flatscreen TVs, showcasing a slideshow of pictures, both vintage and modern. Or, maybe you can even see it with its patrons.

Yes, Breakfast at Cove Cafe seems to bring in the older crowd. Maybe it's just rare that the young boys have all recovered their clothing and made it to the Cove to nurse their hangover, or maybe they are continuing to be fabulous at a place like Lime. Wherever they may be, they are rarely here.

That doesn't mean to say that the place isn't worth a visit. The Cove just feels how a small, gay cafe SHOULD be like. With scrumptious sandwiches and breakfasts, it's hard to resist. Most of the staff aren't eye-candy, but the service is served with conversation. 

With the history on its walls (and some of them sitting in the chairs beside you) it's nice to remember that it's not all about being seen. Just eat.
author: Bryan B.

description:
I've lived in the Castro-ish area for more than 5 years and I only went into the Cove for the first time on Saturday morning for breakfast.  My brunching companion and I had a really good meal and pondered some alternate names for the restaurant:

* The Diner That Shows Mildly Inappropriate Photos on Plasma Screens As You Eat
* Place Where Food Exceeds Expectations
* We Serve Real Hash Browns

So, yes, the hash browns!  They were good and crunchy and I'm not sure if I'm grateful or displeased that I know someplace where I can get some good hash browns so close to my home!  

I'll definitely be back, and next time I want the seat that faces the plasma screen with the sexy menz from the '70s and '80s slideshow!
author: Marcus C.

description:
I had brunch here last week and it was tasty.  I ordered a toasted bagel, cream cheese and lox.  It came with tomato and red onion slices.  The capers cost extra.  Paired it with 2 scrambled eggs and my friend and I shared a short stack of buckwheat pancakes.   Everything was fresh. Good coffee and friendly service also.
Check it out!
author: PictureGirl F.

description: Great Castro spot that serves all-American food. Friendliest serving people and we love Solange and her husband, the owners, who are solid supporters of the LGBT community and have been so for many years.
author: James L.

description:
Through all my criticism of this greasy spoon, through all the jokes to poke at this place, The Cove Cafe has outlived most other restaurants in the Castro, mainly due to its tradition and nostalgic qualities. 

Hundreds of autographed photos used to cover every wall in the restaurant. As you might have guessed, there was a paradigm shift, and they have all been replaced by monolithic plasma TVs that shuffle through all of those old framed profiles. A casualty of the technology epoch.

Oh, the food is acceptable, especially so for a Sunday brunch. But it is a simple greasy spoon menu, hardly worth detailing here. The food passed the heart attack test... meaning that I didn't have one.
author: Daniel C.

description: I tried the NY egg benedict and it wasnt all that great...my husband tried the LA egg benedict and he didn't like it.  The sausage was burnt.  The wait for the food was very long too.
author: sonya h.

description:
If you haven't been to the Cove in years, it's time to go back. I went a few times a number of years ago and hated it. Now I've rediscovered it, and the food is much higher quality. Great Reubens, great patty melts, great breakfast. Refills on your soda...and if you have a craving for chocolate cake, they have a giant slice that I have yet to be able to eat entirely. One time I ordered a buger medium well, and as the waiter started to put it on my table, he said "that doesn't look like medium well, it looks like rare...do you want me to take it back?". 

The ceilings are ugly classroom style, so just don't look up. But the food is great!
author: Nick M.

description:
This review is going to be based on one single sandwich that I had a few weeks ago. Just so you know.

I got their veggie, avocado, cream cheese sandwich. Simple, no? Well, I'm sure it would have been delicious had the avocado not been rotten.

Come on! You know the person making that sandwich saw it, and chose to go ahead and put it on there anyway, hoping I wouldn't notice. And really, for a sandwich that simple to cost over eight dollars, its not too much to ask that it be edible. 

I wanted to take it in there and show them that I saw it, but then my lunch break ended. And someone else paid for it anyway. But I won't be eating there again.
author: Vanessa R.

description: Good food! I have had several dishes here the most note worthy being the eggs benedict. It's a very straight forward cafe restaurant. The staff is friendly and the ambiance is decent. There are several TV monitors on the wall that display different pictures people have sent in, usually gay male themed. It's a good place to go if Harvey's is jammed!
author: Matthew G.

description: Great place for breakfast and cruising. The wall mirrors create an optical illusion making the restaurant appear bigger and definitely allows you to discreetly check out all the action/customers. The management allows you to feel warm and fuzzy as your order is taken and delivered. Food: average. Ambiance/service: Above average. You know, sometimes I like a restaurant not because of the food but because of the overall experience. This is one such dining establishment.
author: Charlie T.

description: Let me first say that the Cove's staff is fabulous.  They are all very sweet, and always so friendly during the stay.  The food is mediocre at best.  HOWEVER, the prices are ridiculously high.  Even without any alcohol a simple breakfast can cost you up yo $20.00!!!  Of course, that is with Iced Tea which is horrible.  I don't know if it is a mix, but the tea is wretched.  Bring the prices down, get a new iced tea, but KEEP THE STAFF!!!  :-)  They are so great.
author: Matt A.

description:
The Cove Cafe on Castro has been my favorite Breakfast or meal place on The Castro. I mostly arrive for breakfast when I have the time. I'm always greeted and treated with the customer respect that should be received by an establishment.

I enjoy the staff as well. They are very courteous and services has been fantastic. And if you're lucky and your favorite server has time to chat, you will receive a minute of undivided attention. 

I have mentioned a few times to the owners who are a couple, how I enjoy entering their establishment and how I enjoy the recently interior remodel. 

This is a great Breakfast hang-out for sure. You should check it out.
author: Donald P.

description:
This is the place to go for home cookin in the Castro. I especially enjoy breakfast here. I don't go for no fancy stuff at the Cove, I get the 2-2-2 and coffee; 2 eggs, 2 pancakes and 2 strips of crispy bacon!

If I'm out for breakfast on the weekend, this is one of my top choices.
author: Jerry M.

description: Great little spot right on Castro street. It's the perfect place to grab breakfast or brunch. The food is good, the prices are reasonable, and the service is awesome.
author: Armon D.

description: What a wondeful spot! Great service and delicious food. And so many nice suprises like homemade soda bread and awesome cherry pie. Throw is some good classic oldies and I'm all set. Though it doesn't look like a typical diner inside, it's still cosy, and the food is better than most diners I've been to. Great meatloaf and patty melts. Our server was not only a sweetheart, but had great suggestions throughout our meal. And another nice man working at the time brought sneezing patrons napkins and stopped me from leaving without my umbrella. I am happy to have a nice cosy comfort food spot in a neighborhood I like to visit.
author: Isabel L.

description:
I am surprised that there are only 16 reviews for this place - you would think there would be so many people go here, given its location in the heart of gay-spring-break.

We had to wait a few minutes for a table, but it was a nice touch to provide us with excellent, spicy bloody marys while we stood and waited.

The place is nice enough, the food is great diner-fare, the service was good, and the price was fine.

The one downside for me was the forty-two inch plasma TVs mounted on each of the four walls - total overkill in such a small space. The TVs were playing apparently random still photos of (mostly) gay (mostly) men. I guess the idea is to "put it all out there", show folks as they are, and gays as "people just like you" or some such message. 

But, the whole thing is a little bit too "in yer face" - and just too distracting - I spent much of the meal trying to figure out just how many (excellent) eggs-over-easy and half-stacks they would have to sell to pay for all those huge TVs!
author: Kingpin X.

description:
I've had amazing Idaho trout here for brunch and a bunch of other tasty dishes, too. It always strikes me as a little more money than I expect to pay, but really the service is excellently friendly and the food is good. 

The photographs that used to hang on the walls are now on TVs. This is probably good because the framed versions were a little too much--so many faces, and most of them must have been lost during the 80s and early 90s. It's important to have those there, but it's an odd thing to eat around. Then again, how nice for regulars to see old friends.
author: Tyler S.

description:
I'm all for neighborhood restaurants, but The Cove just didn't cut it for breakfast.  I had the corned beef hash, which required both tabasco and tons of salt (on corned beef?!?!?!).  It wasn't really awful, just sort of lacking in flavor and disproportionately expensive for what it was.

There are better options close by.
author: Matt O.

description:
I've here twice for dinner; go on a Friday and there's fish and chips with delicious (homemade!) french fries! Add to that a waitstaff that is always polite and call you "sweatheart"... and add to that the time I went with my sister and they were convinced she was Ellen Page from "Juno"... and I am a huge fan.

Not a shocker that something so lovely and fried can give you a stomach ache, but totally worth it just the same.
author: Katie R.

description:
Hmm... how to put it lightly. the food was nothing to remember. boring as is the place. a cafe should have some character. i would imagine. or some imagination. anything. 

my omelet lacked flavor. lacked... satisfaction. not asking for the world, but definitely less butter on the muffin. wow. 

did i miss something? gary felt the same.  the decor reminded me of punishment for some reason.  "no, you do not get to enjoy your surroundings while eating mediocre food."

hard to keep trying new places that do not measure up to simple and tasteful, but more on the lacking and lackluster.

i make better old fashion hash browns.  flavor.  yes, you want flavor.
author: Benjamin B.

description: Stopped in to the Cove Cafe on a wednesday around 3pm for a cup of soup because im old and it sounded delicious. The Cove is right across from the Castro theatre and had a cozy vibe and nice enough service. It wasnt stellar and it wasnt awful but with all of the other amazing places to eat nearby, they'd need to step up their game for me to come back.
author: Lee P.

description:
My roommates and I are BIG on brunch, so when someone told us to try out the Cove right down the street from our apartment we literally ran over there.
I had delicious pancakes and hash browns.  My roommate had a wonderful hamlet (ham and cheese omelet haha).
My favorite parts of the meal had to be the quick service and the digital photography on half naked gay men on the tv screen.
The Cove Cafe is my new favorite Sunday morning spot.
author: Jordan D.

description: Standard diner food is nothing special, but the service is friendly and the place is good for watching people on the street and in the restaurant.
author: Mandy H.

description:
Waffles for reals.  Fast service. Gay and pleasant!

For a really nice Sunday brunch for a few more bills, Catch is around the corner on Market.   But that's a whole different scene than this.  Not that these are popular prices, the Cove is always over on the expensive side of that line.  It's simply that the Cove is a diner, and Catch is something finer.  However, the Cove Cafe has something hard to find.  No, not a hard man silly.  I'm sure that if you can't find that in many other establishments in THIS nabe, then you're not really trying.  Let me go ahead and spill the beans.  The Cove has good waffles!  And y'all waffle luvahs know how hard it is to get that shxt hooked up right...can I get an amen?  If you like waffles for brunch on Sundays, then you can say hallelujah here.  If you like them all week long, another benefit of the Cove is that it's a brunch-level breakfast menu all week long.  Give me two hallelujahs!!  Oh, the well-fed folks are singin' now...

Trivial side note.  The smooth jazz TV is interesting...well, musically it is completely un-interesting.  Ironically though, the music and record industry trivia on the screen is actually interesting, in a "if you like Trivial Pursuit" kinda way.  You don't think about it long either way, because they take your order in a hurry and get the food in front of you almost as quickly.  Takes a gay place to upgrade smooth jazz..

Plus, I can't say for sure, 'cause I'm on the other team, but the Cove seems like a damn good place to be gay.  

I could make a bad pun about waffling over whether to give the Cove 3 stars or 4.  Even bemoan the lack of the Holy Grailish 1/2 star that Yelp lacks!  But this place has been steadil good y enough for long enough to deserve a legit 4.
author: Ted R.

description:
This is one of the few places you can go alone (i.e., no problem asking for a "table for one") without feeling lonely, as the staff is always super-nice and you can tell they love working there.  I always try to get a window seat to people-watch, but I'd sit anywhere to go there.  Even during street festivals it's not too crowded.  The bathroom is always clean, although a few times the line has been long since there's only one "stall."

I remember I went there one time to meet my boyfriend after getting out of the hospital for four days (minor neck surgery) and it felt like I was getting a special, home-cooked meal.

I love getting the sourdough special with fries or side salad and the deep fried cauliflower appetizer!  Make sure whatever you get to ask for the malt vinegar!
author: Joseph H.

description:
hmm.  I've gone into cove cafe twice (since the welcome home cafe next door closed for good).

perhaps it's not fair to judge them back-to-back against one of my favorite breakfast spots in the city (welcome home, natch)... but I'm gonna go right ahead and do just that, because the contrast between the two says a lot about the quality.

before ripping into the food, I just want to say that the people working at cove cafe are great.  they've all been warm and friendly and efficient.  no gripes there at all.

the food though.  sigh.  hit or miss.

under the, "miss" category: nine-dollar mimosas that taste like boozy ginger ale mixed with sunny delight.  don't get that, especially since their fresh squeezed OJ is genuinely very good.  bargain basement champagne at a huge mark-up, methinks.

next miss: eggs benedict.  a.k.a. rock-hard, dried out english muffin crowned with *turkey* "canadian bacon" (sorry, canada)... splooged with this bizarrely colored gray-ish sauce (which, BTW had broken) cut with OJ or something else to thin it out.  bleeeeeech.  if you're going to serve crap like this, at least provide a chain saw.

third miss: hash browns.  an oil soaked and completely soggy mess absolutely lacking any sort of crunchy outer yumminess.  pure goo.  flavorless goo.

that said, a couple of days later I carefully avoided the eggs bene-grossidict and tried the special: chorizo, pepper jack and avacado omelet.  it was pretty damn good -- but, sadly, accompanied by the same failed attempt at hash browns, along with sourdough toast (which, magically, was transmorgified into whole wheat toast between the kitchen and my table).

for christ's sake, give the oil squeeze bottle a rest.  the hash browns will thank for for it!

some good stuff here to be sure.  too bad it's such a crap shoot in the end though.  if I'm going to plop down $25 for breakkies, I want consistent goodness.
author: Mark B.

description:
The Cove is an institution. It's been on Castro for so long. The staff is friendly and sweet, but Kristi (the blond) is the only competent one to get you in and out at lunch when you have to get back to work. If she's not there, I hesitate to stop in.
 The food is good, the bathroom is clean, but they painted it a weird color. I miss the photos rather than the tv screens. The screens seem incongruous to the rest of the atmosphere, though I must say it was a blast to watch the Inauguration on them there. But generally, I miss the old photos. 
  The coffee and the orange juice are suburb.
author: Jane L.

description: If you just want good food but don't mind a sparse atmosphere then this is your spot. Nothing blew me away but the service was friendly albeit a little spotty. All combined, this is why you won't have to wait in line just to eat. A step up from a Denny's but not an experience by any means.
author: Isaac S.

description:
For a cafe, Cove Cafe does a great job bringing out subtle and interest flavors out of all their dishes. While the menu and the presentation of the food a pretty standard, I've often found that things I've tried here are some of the best of food I've had - especially at a cafe. The soups and chocolate croissant bread pudding are terrific.

The staff are all very unique and much more engaging than most wait staffs. The walls are all covered with photos of different gay couples from the Castro area.
author: Tom W.

description:
Ever since Welcome Home closed its doors a few months ago, I have made The Cove my default diner experience in The Castro.   The staff is always incredibly friendly and provides good, accurate service.

The food is very good but not great, and considering that the owners of the place own a more upscale restaurant elsewhere in San Francisco, I am somewhat surprised and slightly disappointed at this.  But the food is always delicious and served promptly, so the hot food is hot, the cold food is cold.  Their coffee is a bit inconsistent, though, and sometimes it's just a little watery - usually nice and strong and rich, though.

I enjoy the photo slideshows on the big LCD televisions, sometimes they put movies up there, and sometimes it's one of Comcast's music channels, so you can see the info for whatever song is playing.  That's a nice touch, as I found a cool jazz artist that way to add to my massage music playlists.

I often am there for breakfast, and order the Chicken Fried Steak and Eggs, with a side of fruit salad, too.  Over easy eggs are always perfectly cooked, and the thinly sliced scallions garnishing the gravy is a nice touch and added a slightly exotic element to a traditional breakfast.

For dinner, I have ordered half the menu item on the dinner menu.  I haven't yet had a bad experience, so I'm happy about that.

Overall, The Cove is comfortable, with good food and service.  The could take it up a notch with a bit more attention to detail in their dinner menu, and get five stars, but four's better than a sharp stick in the eye, eh?
author: Paul B.

description:
What is the secret to this old school meets cali diner castro institution?

The people.
The neighorhood.
The family owned business.

Its local.

I come back for the hashbrowns. They are excellent.
Diner food fare with updated mid price options.
author: Joe R.

description:
The Cove Cafe (nee the Norse Cove) was once what was wrong with food in the Castro, but now that many restaurants with sophisticated menus and ambiance pepper the neighborhood (if not clutter), the Cove is a warm and cozy comfort food station that is unpretentious and basic.  Friendly waiters make you feel at home.

I went back to the Cove for the first time (perhaps five?) in years this morning.   Perched in one of the two front sunny window tables, I ate the delicious pancakes with a friend of mine.  Although their coffee needs a serious upgrade, it is a pleasant, if a bit bland, neighborhood spot.

Long ago, before the premier of the real Luna Piena, 2323, and others, the Castro was a full food eateries whose owners who offered mediocre, boring food to those whose patronage depended more on the guys on the Castro, than the menu.  Fortunately for out palates, the restaurateurs have evolved.  

The Cove Cafe remains a local favorite.
author: Adam R.

description:
Well what can I tell you, it's breakfast here breakfast there, pretty much I've tried all the breakfast place in the Castro. I mean after you woke up with a stranger you pretty much need to eat something to get your system runnin and conscious and all that, joking.
Anyway, good place, support independent biz and it's an institution with all pics hanging on the wall. Get a table by the window you'll get to see everyone that walked by the strip.
author: John L.

description: Service is superp, friendly staff. Food isn't that great though. Cove owners, please consider tasting your cook's food cuz it they must be doing something to sabotage the taste of your food. How can pancakes taste so weird? I'm not even a picky eater. See my other reviews. Please please invest on a better cook or train your current one. We ordered omelette, pancakes, eggs Benedict on corn beef hash and they just didn't taste right. I want your restaurant to last. Please do something about the cook that u had for breakfast today. We'll come back n try again soon.
author: Jen R.

description: We wanted to grab something to eat before going out for a friends birthday...something really quick and my friend said this place was pretty good.  I couldn't figure out what to get, so I stuck with a typical salad.  I got a Chef Salad and it was exactly what you expected for a salad.  Their presentation was good, it was in a wooden bowl with each of the ingredients separated so I was able to mix it myself.  I guess the thing that made it stand out the most was the size of the salad...IT WAS HUGE!  If my memory serves me correctly I believe it was right around $9-$10 dollars.  I'd go again, but I wouldn't drive all the way to the castro for that specifically.
author: Ashley J.

description: One of the only original Castro businesses left. The BLT is my number one choice here. I had the fried chicken basket today. It was different. It was greasy. Not a bad thing though. Not many places in the neighborhood that have fried chicken. It is not a regular on their menu. I would eat it again if I saw it on the menu.
author: Ryan M.

description:
Breakfast is great  Lunch and dinner not so hot, that said I go there a lot anyway.  Trying to be upscale with the dinner menu, but I'm not looking for upscale, this is a diner, I want diner food.  

They took down the pictures and put up the monitors, but half the time they play music and put the music choice title screens up????  Pictures were better on wall, they seem to have fewer on the electronic version than they had on the wall, which negates the reason for the monitors.  

The owners and staff are the best.  People stay there a LONG time, that says a lot.  I've lived here 7 years and some of them have been here that long.

One thing I can't stand.  Milk for your coffee.  Yuck Yuck Yuck Yuck
author: Stu J.

description:
What is the number one thing you want in a diner?  Love.  Yep.  You got it. Good ole' downhome unabashed love. The Cove Cafe is full of it.   

We just left there from a Saturday lunch, and felt absolutely welcomed by both the wait staff and the fellow patrons.  They enthusiastically told us about the history of the place, the people who frequent there, the lentil soup, and they invited us to bring our photos for their digital walls.   We're a straight couple (not always so popular in the Castro), and we greatly appreciated feeling a vibe that was both relaxing and accepting.

We loved the warmth and neighborhood-feel so much that we're sure to be back.  Diner food is diner food, but diner love is finer love.  Stop in and get yourself some.
author: yelposity o.

description:
The Cove Cafe is your basic neighborhood diner -- if your neighborhood happens to have video montages of their past gay clientele.   Gay or Straight, you'll be cheerfully greeted by the friendly staff.

Again, the food is basic diner cuisine, but well made and served hot from the kitchen.  On Friday's, the clam chowder is especially good.

What makes this place we keep going back to -- other than the good food -- is the friendly staff who make you feel at home.

If you are in the Castro, and looking for a quick bite to eat, I highly recommend the Cove Cafe to get your bodily fuel so you can hit the neighborhood running.
author: Karl W.

description: The food is as average as average can get.  However I love going there because the staff is nice and enjoyable and it is a step back and feels gay 1970-1992 and I love that and want it to live on for that and we have a ton of average or even less than average places to eat in the area, so why not keep this one alive.
author: Joseph F.

description:
I am a reviewer of few words... also of few culinary 'needs'. All I need is average service and average food to be an average amount of happy about going to a place. Cove's food is well above average (not superb) and there is a better than average variety on the menu(3 different types of Benedict, waffles, challah French toast) , the service is fantastic (and the servers themselves are terrific people).

I give it 5 stars for the c-c-c-combo of all of the above. I return here when I have breakfast in the Castro because I know I will leave satisfied and smiling.
author: David V.

description:
Stopped in after a late evening of work. $25.00 including tip for an entrée and small side salad.

The food has improved as of late and most of the staff is great. It  does gets a little old the be called "Sweeties" every 8 minutes by a 50 year old man. Other than that it is a good place for  a Sunday brunch or early evening dinner.
author: J.B. A.

description:
I've been to this typical breakfast joint/diner many times (all for breakfast) and will keep going back.  I certainly don't frequent it for the environment, a somewhat typical diner style place aside from a TV with an ongoing slide show of different people.  Good music -- sometimes a little bit too loud.

The service is consistently inconsistent.   Many times we have had attentive waitstaff despite the place being crowded.  Other times we've been ignored when the place has been close to empty.  One recent visit we encountered a very unfriendly host with a ton of attitude.

The food is solid and for a great price.  The menu includes "fat kid's delight" food as well as healthy options.  It is one of the few restaurants that still have real hash browns (why do so many restaurants consider home fries (cut-up potato pieces/chunks) the same as hash browns??).  

Decent coffee but no (yes... I'll say it) latte machine.  I have coffees during the week.  On a sunny weekend morning I like to treat myself to a latte.  Is that a crime?  Unfortunately, no lattes at the Cove Cafe.  Otherwise a good spot for a nice bite to eat.
author: George H.

description: The Cove has the best homemade Hollandaise in San Francisco!! And they serve hash browns, not home fries for breakfast :)  The breakfast and lunch are especially great. The food is 'comfort' food but creative, worldly, and very very tasty, for ALL mealtimes. Menu is quite extensive for a neighborhood cafe. The owner (Solange) and staff are super friendly and courteous beyond, you REALLY feel like you are family when you are there. Love it. If I lived there I would go everyday, but I have to settle for twice a year.
author: Charlotte M.

description: The food is good. Nothing fancy. American greasy spoon. The service: an abomination! Horrendous! I will never eat there again. I had to wait a quarter of an hour after getting my water, before I was even asked by a waiter what I wanted. I saw people who came in after me give their orders and get their meals while I was still sucking on my water. When I arrived at the restaurant, I had had 45 minutes until I need to be somewhere else. I figured enough time. It took 45 minutes from when I walked-in to when my food finally arrived. I had to take it to go.
author: Robert A.

description: best kept secret in the Castro! amazing service, tasty food, you feel like you're eating at home. love you guys.
author: Castro Reviewer S.

description: Just discovered the best executed pastry item ever. The made-to-order $2 glazed bacon-encrusted donut at the Cove.  Forget other donuts, which are not worth getting fat over. This is. Almost crunchy on its browned outside; not-too-sweet with the perfect crumb inside. So ungreasy that it beggars belief  it was ever even kissed by oil, much less raised and reared in it.  Platonic essence of fried-ness. After glazing,  donut is pressed into crispy crumbled bacon. Bacon sprinkles! Channeled Homer Simpson and shared  rapture with the owner, a lovely woman who has  tinkered with a regular customer's family recipe to perfect it. The rest of breakfast: freshly squeezed OJ (cold and tangy-sweet, no bitterness), toast and eggs, etc., was snappily prepared and served hot. If I lived in SFO, this'd be my go-to. Maybe I'll move.
author: Sam M.

description:
we had sunday brunch  here and it was really interesting how homogeneous the crowd were yesterday......hot looking men with their leather outfit, some just had this leather thingy strapped on their biceps, shaved hair, rugged and some clean cut looking....it was a total congregation of sizzling, stunning group of men on this particular day.

the food was satisfactory and sufficient.

the chorizo scrambled in egg whites was flavorful..and the hash brown was nicely browned and it was also crispy!

the south beach special in egg whites with spinach was quite tasty and the two small round slices of the turky canadian bacon was also decent.

coffee here was weak...but the fresh OJ was savory & invigorating.

we received a very welcoming & attentive service from 3 staff! great customer indeed!

however, they charged too much for the paltry dishes they give you.
author: Nelle A.

description: A good spot for a decent breakfast, but there's nothing impressive about the rest of the menu. If you've ever lived in, passed through, or heard about the Castro, there's a good chance your photo's on the wall. Good people watching from the window tables as long as you're not cheating on the boyfriend, since those who can see can be seen in return. Personally, I'd take the few extra steps down the street to Welcome Home. The line will be longer, but there's a good reason why.
author: Gourmet G.

description: A whole lotta bears!  Should be called the Cave.  They are really nice in here, though.  It's simple and comfy and close to home.  I really miss Eddie's Cafe near my old place... sigh.  But the Cove has much better food in my opinion than any of the diners in the area.  Although it's fun sometimes to people-watch at Orphan Andy's, sometimes I want a quiet, peaceful breakfast.  But they actually serve lunch and dinner too, so check it out.
author: Aaron W.

description: I went on a Saturday at around 3:30pm and they were still serving breakfast items; that is definitely a plus!  The food was good, but the service was kind of slow even though there were only 3 other tables occupied.    My main complaint is that I asked the server for water three times and it was never brought to the table.
author: Stephanie D.

description: Our waiter, "Chuck of the Castro", welcomed us like family and treated us to a wonderful meal.  I had the Pumping IronMan Special (grilled chicken breast, spinach scrambled eggs, cottage cheese and an awesome bowl of fresh fruit) and my wife had a marvelous eggs benedict.  If you're a resident of the Castro district you already know how good it is, and if you're passing through add it to your list!
author: Patrick P.

description:
Looks can be deceiving....Menu looks tasty, but beware.  Food was awful.

The iced tea tasted like I was sucking on a chlorinated tea bags, the biscuit was burnt, and the service......well....I don't really know, we only saw the waiter 2 times during our entire horrid meal.

Suggestion: Change food distributors, buy decent quality food, and don't burn it.  Get a water filter....Refrain from buying biscuits out of a container that pops when you throw it on the ground. 

2 stars as the menu is creative, and the photos were interesting to look at.
author: Mike O.

description: The soups can be very, very good. The rest of the food I experience there is fine, not great, not horrible.  The service can be a tad slow.  A "greasy pink spoon".
author: Don m.

description: Hmm. Well. It's your typical cheap cafe food (& I don't mean cheap in price). The food looked bland the atmosphere and decor are in desperate need of a make over. It reminds me of this lil cafe in my old hometown where all the old folks go to eat.
author: Kris C.

description: Cute little place.  Here during Pride in the Castro so it was a little crazy.  The Cove seemed like a bastion of happy queerness.  Everyone was in great spirits and the service was quick and helpful.  Since we eat gluten free the south beach lunch was the way to go.  Pretty yummy.  They were very accommodating about gluten free and double checked ingredients for us.  Plus...they have rootbeer barrel candy at the cash register.  Score.
author: Kim K.

description: Now THAT'S a bloody Mary! Mmmm...totally worth the $6 as there was plenty of alcohol, just enough pepper, and tabasco marrying harmoniously with the tomato juice.  My girlfriend had Solange's lemonade and enjoyed that as well.  She also raved about the freshness of the ingredients in the Greek omelette.  I had the corned beef hash and it was good but I wouldn't say it was great.  Coffee and service were pleasant and the prices are reasonable.  Best of all, though it was crowded to capacity, I didn't have to strain to hear or be heard.
author: Jill D.

description: I went here for a late lunch on Saturday.  Atmosphere is relaxed with a number of TV screens adorning the walls.  I had the chicken scramble which was quite good.  Portions were good and presentation was a few notches above your standard greasy spoon.  Price for value is ok.
author: Parker W.

description: My little sister (8-years-old)  and I went here last night before the last showing of the Sing-along  Wizard of Oz   I got the time for the movie slightly off. so thought it would be too late to eat after  the movie.  I also      wanted a place without any "scene".    This restaurant was perfect.  We got really efficient     service and the waiter was really nice to us.  She got mac and cheese and I got a cheeseburger (and wine, because I don't sing sober, lol.)  The mac and cheese was excellent (though my weird sister thought it was too cheesy, lol.)  and the burger, though not the best., was very good.  It also came with scrumptious curly fries.  I got the impression also that the waiter knew that we were in a hurry and  acted accordingly.  (Since I had us decide before going and just ordered as we wre seated, that may have been a clue, lol.)  It was pretty  accessible.  One or two wheelchairs would be fine, but not sure about a whole group.   I would definitely come  again for some non attitude food!
author: Sascha B.

description: I've been going to Cove Cafe ever since I moved to San Francisco 16 years ago. It is a nice cozy and warm place with a very good selection of dishes. And the prices are very reasonable. Brunches on weekends are really fun.
author: Bill R.

description: I had breakfast here a few times and it was generally pretty good, although one time the bacon was so underdone I sent it back because it could have made me sick! I understand they have a busy restaurant, but undercooked food is a hazard. So for that, I knocked them down a star (otherwise they'd get three from me).
author: Brooke H.

description: this place is so fracking cute. and the service is personable. major love.
author: S B.

description:
do not eat here ...the health dept had to close the resturant for finding mouse in the kitchen or dishwasher room !! 

uncleannnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnnn
author: nami k.

description: Best wait staff in san francisco, best soup on the planet.
author: James M.

description: How do you mess up breakfast? Pancakes were the same as McDonald's pancakes ( don't get me wrong, I love some McD pancakes every now and then). The corned beef hash and eggs benedict was flavorless. Never again will I eat there. Plus, the service was indifferent at best.
author: p b.

description: Came here on a Sunday morning to find the place packed with people. The food took a while to come out but it was worth it. I ordered the vegatable eggs benedict that was really good. Their hash browns are fresh and filling. The servers are really nice and friendly. The sitting is really tight, you can hear everything the people next to you are saying, whether you want to or not. However, i would come back again.
author: Mark L.

description: One of the reasons I love the Castro.  If you are expecting a "Fine" dining experience, then go elsewhere, but if you want a good meal, at a decent price, and want to feel comfortable and welcomed, then this is the place for you.  I've had the pleasure of eating at this little place for years, and whenever I can, I pop in for either breakfast, lunch or dinner.  It's nice to walk into a restaurant, be welcomed by name, and enjoy some good old fashioned american fare.  The owners, and staff have always made me feel like a part of the family here..
author: Tony K.

description: The food is fine here. The staff is very friendly and the owner is very generous in donating food to nonprofit benefits and supporting the local community. It has a neighborhoody charm. I only wish it was open for late night dining.
author: Jeff S.

description: One of my favorite places for Sunday Brunch.  The crowds are fun and diverse - ranging from couples to families to the after-church crowd, and if you get a window seat, the people watching on Castro St. is quite fun, too.  The food is pretty decent - considering that it's essentially diner food - but the servers and decor are what make it worthwhile, I think.
author: Carly P.

description: Nice little cafe to go to for anytime of the day! They have great breakfast meals and good service!
author: Mel P.

description: I've probably eaten 500 meals here over the years.  It's my go-to, value for the money, gonna-be-satisfied place.  Breakfasts are wonderful (corned beef or turkey hash are both excellent!), the lunch sandwiches, particularly the hot sandwiches like the sourdough special or the reuben are awesome and come with huge sides (fries, salad or soup) and the staff have always treated me like family.  There are a lot of healthy options on the menu if you want to avoid the more traditional diner fare.  They are known for their quality soups, too, and always have three or four varieties (including vegan) on the menu, changing daily.  It's also very, very consistent, which I really appreciate...you don't have to wonder if your order is going to be the same quality each time you go.  The decor is simple but pleasant and love the video montages of the old photos of customers - a nice touch in the ever-changing Castro.  Five stars for relative value - no, its not Gary Danko, but that's not what they are about.  Thank you, Solange!
author: Timothy M.

description: I would love this place more if I hadn't found hair on my grilled cheese that one time. And why isn't anyone ever in there? Its sad. But it is nice to have a quiet place to eat when the rest of the 'hood is jam-packed with men trying to get into the Bar or the Sausage Factory (don't even get me started). Great grilled cheese, great mac & cheese, great soup, great fries, great photos of patrons - I love the personal touch. But they could kick the cleanliness factor up a notch.
author: Katie D.

description: Great hash browns and breakfast at this Castro street diner. The OJ is freshly squeezed and there are tons of pictures to look at on the walls. Very neighborhood feel. I used to go here often when i lived in the neighborhood and its always a stop when i'm in the city.
author: Edwyn A.

description: I would go for the turkey hash alone! And the soups are generous and very hearty. Always a fun buzz in there, and generally good for a glorified greasy spoon diner kind of place.
author: Eric P.

description: I love the Cove.  For being a homestyle food cafe they really make darn tasty stuff.  The soup is great, but their basket of chicken is too die for.  I'm also a big fan of their Reubens.  It's a great place to eat on a budget as the prices are very reasonable.  I love the fact that they keep bringing you refills of soda it little carafes.  The service is friendly too.  They have a cool tv system that plays all the photos that they used to have up on the walls, very neat to see all the Castro history play out on the screens while you dine.  Definately highly recommended to tourists for that fact alone.  Also there's great people watching if you can sit close to the front or in the bay window.
author: Michael D.

description:
i was going to give them a three but because sunday brunch is never hard to get into, four stars it is.

staff is mildly aloof until you come in for about the fourth time and then conversations might be had. In my case, she let me borrow her lighter. wow! i tipped extra as well.

I always go with the 2-2-2 (eggs-pancakes or french toast-bacon or sausage) because after a long night i usually dont have it in me to think. the omelets are hearty but remind me a cheap sushi, in how it fills you up for now and you find yourself hungry very soon after. my eggs are never runny when i dont want them to be, sausage isnt burnt, they even leave off the dollop of butter i hate on my french toast!

ive never been past 4pm and have never eaten anything besides breakfast. so cant help you in that department...well for the time being.

The cafe is always the typical cute older gay men and their friends talking about either their night out or just catching up. the crowd isnt very noisy and the turn around time is actually damn near perfect.

the large mimosa will set you back 10bucks, is made with freshed squeezed, and guaranteed get you feeling a little more generous when it comes tipping time.
author: Chan W.

description: I went here for Dinner. Pretty good food and service though nothing too special. It's basically your typical neighborhood diner. I'd eat here again but can't say there's anything particular on the menu I'd crave.
author: Galeet L.

description: I love this place.  The staff is bitchy (in a very funny & entertaining way) & efficient.  The only thing I don't like about it is the fact that I always seem to get stuck next to a table of angry lesbians.  What are they trying to tell me?!  I like the pole, not the hole...unless I'm enticed by pancakes or something shiny - then, all bets are off.
author: Charlene E.

description:
we had a work meeting on saturday that required a two-top and some quiet time, and cove fit the bill. there was a nice bustle about the cafe but it wasn't super obnoxious like lime. i had a medley breakfast of scrambled eggs, french toast, and bacon - all done nicely, but not like "OMG THIS SHIT IS AMAZING." it's breakfast! (shrug)

free refills does make my heart happy, and our server was very warm to us, which is a plus. i'm a little neutral about the joint but would not be adverse to coming back to try dinner. the fresh-squeezed OJ is really amazing.
author: Jenz y.

description: I walked by here how many times and I never went in? Really a shame as this is an excellent restaurant. The quality of the food is much better than you would expect on Castro. It is decidedly non greasy and the menu leans healthy while still offering comfort style fare. Additional props go to the extremely friendly staff who do an excellent job of taking care of you.
author: William N.

description: I've only been there for breakfast but each time it's been superb.  As a previous reviewer mentioned, they're super-flexible when it comes to additions/subtractions to your meal - they don't even blink an eye.  And the staff is very sweet and attentive.
author: Moira D.

description:
The pancakes are tasty. The rest of the menu is predictably diner/greasy spoon/short order cook and nothing particularly interesting on the menu that one can't get around the corner at Orphan Andy's or once could down the block when the glorious Welcome Home was still in operation, selling drinks in gigantic Texas Ware plastic cups filled with that weird rabbit pellet ice i so very much love ... ice that's so much easier to crunch on while awaiting a refill. 
But anyway, this Cove Cafe place is TOTALLY overpriced. i mean $13 for a BLT? this is not a place in the Financial District, it's a place in the actually dingy and depressing first block of Castro off Market Street. the wait staff is disinterested at best and possibly actually clinically retarded at worst. i cannot fathom why it's always full ... but usually with older gays who must have been eating there since Castro was actually gay and interesting. 
the one plus that does not, alas, warrant another star is the endless video show of former customers ... kind of a paean to the Castro that once was but never shall be. 
Stick with Orphan Andy's for disinterested wait staff and greasy spoon deliciousness.
author: Kevin M.

description: Thank god. I found a diner. The only place to have bacon and eggs in the morning in the Castro.  None of their food is outstanding or surprising, but it is exactly what you would expect.
author: Geronimo G.

description: a very nice traditional, cozy and friendly atmosphere. I am never disappointed.
author: James B.

description: The Cove cafe is a great neighborhood restaurant. Outstanding breakfast and lunch and just a great atmosphere. Not to mention the owners are some of the nicest people I have ever met. They greet everyone with open arms. I LOVE this place.
author: krislyn P.

description: Tomato soup to die for, good comfort food menu  but avoid the turkey pot pie - it totally sucks.
author: TIM E.

description:
at lunch try either the meatloaf/potato sandwich or the one that substitutes turkey for meatloaf.  also recommended is the macaroni and cheese.

the pictures are now on a TV screen and new paint and curtains adds a fresh look to the place.
author: Richard D.

description: they serve up good basic breakfasts here. i like that they serve up real hash browns! the decor ain't fancy - if that matters to you. it's very plain and basic and has a little bit of divey-ness to it. kinda wish they had a liquor licence so i could order a bloody mary with vodka - not soju. with that said, i think i'll be swayed more to go to harvey's in the future  instead of this place on account of harvey's good bloody marys. but still, this place is another good breakfast option for the castro.
author: James J.

description: I've eaten here before, on previous trips to SF and had fairly good experiences, which is why we went on this trip, 7/22 to 7/28.  We stopped in for breakfast on Monday, 7/27.  I was surprised to see the remodel and all the pictures on the walls gone.  That aside, the service was HORRIBLE.  There were only 5 active tables in the place and two staff on the floor.  With that ratio you would have thought the service would have been pretty good.  Too bad the two staff working were to busy talking to pay attention to their customers.  We both had orders with side beverages (milk, OJ) and those never arrived.  They brewed a fresh pot of decaf coffee..but never once stopped by for a refill or to see if everything was ok with the meals.  Doubtful I'll go there again on our trip next year.
author: Jeff M.

description: good and comfortable food...I like the breakfast here since Welcome Home closed.
author: Denny R.

description: I strongly disagree. This is one of the biggest rip off lunches I have had in a long time. I expect everything in the Castro to be overpriced. I had a simple hamburger and soup. First it cost almost 10 bucks. The burger tasted like rubber and the soup although good was pint size. I am going to go to more chain restaurants because I am tired of being screwed by businesses I am supposed to support because they are gay and locally owned.
author: Joel W.

description:
this remains tops in the castro casual eating places.
can never go wrong with any item on their menu.

friendly, stable staff -  new chairs in the last two years
and a moderate price rise.  price increases are inevitable!

recommended!
author: Richard D.

description: meager amounts of terrible food at really high prices.
author: Brian K.
